locations.description:
This contemporary hotel is a 7-minute walk from the beach and 4.1 km from La Sagrada Familia. 

All rooms offer upscale decor and custom-designed beds, plus flat-screen TVs, minibars, coffeemakers and paid WiFi. Executive rooms offer free WiFi and access to the Executive Lounge’s free breakfast and evening appetizers. Suites add separate living areas.

Breakfast is available (fee), and there’s a restaurant serving Mediterranean/Catalan cuisine, as well as a chic bar and a cafe. There's also a fitness center, a seasonal outdoor pool, a children's pool and saunas. Additional amenities include a ballroom, 15 meeting rooms and a business center.
locations.name: Hilton Diagonal Mar

schedule.description:
Upstream University is an intensive program designed to share knowledge about the different ways of contributing to OpenStack like providing new features, writing documentation, participating in working groups, and so forth. The educational program is built on the principle of open collaboration and will teach the students how to find information and navigate the intricacies of the project’s technical tools and social interactions in order to get the contributions accepted. The live one and a half day class is focusing on hands-on practice like the students can use a development environment to work on real-life bug fixes or new features and learn how to test, prepare and upload them for review. The attendees are also given the opportunity to join a mentoring program to get further help and guidance on their journey to become an active and successful member of the OpenStack community.

Please note that Upstream University is a 2 Day program. An RSVP to Day 1 is an automatic RSVP to Day 2.
schedule.title: Upstream University - Day 1

schedule.description:
RSVP REQUIRED: https://canonicaltraining.eventbrite.com


Attendees must have a Full Access pass to the OpenStack Summit Barcelona in order to attend this training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

What you will learn: 

  • Canonical's Openstack charms (e.g. core openstack, barbican, designate, etc.) 
  • Charming best practices (e.g. utilizing layering, reactive, contributing, git review process, etc.) which will be helpful as part of an Openstack Lifecycle, Operation, and Development. 
  • Continuous Integration/Continuous Development practices that are implemented within Canonical's DevOps team which would be beneficial as partner's/customer's grow their own DevOps practices. 
  • Furthermore, attendees will be able to discuss their Openstack charm questions with Canonical's Openstack Leads and Technical Architects who will provide insights into upstream development, compatibility matrix, and tips/tricks on charm development. Taking advantage of this unique opportunity will be a benefit to developers, managers, and operational personnel as they venture into the inception and growth of their Openstack solution and operational business. 

Pre-requisites:

You should know basic Openstack.

Other information:

All equipment and materials will be provided. Please note this session will end at lunchtime.
schedule.title: RSVP Required: Canonical Half-Day Morning Training - Charm School 101

schedule.description:
The OpenStack UX project will be conducting a series of ten usability studies to identity both opportunities and pain points associated using the project APIs.   
 
A link will be provided on the OpenStack UX wiki if you’re an operator and would like to schedule a time to participate in the study.
schedule.title: Help Improve OpenStack! Participate in the Project API Usability Study with Operators

schedule.description:
The Command Presence Workshop (CPW) has been recognized by Anita Borg Institute and Harvard Business Review. It is intended to teach participants how to handle “senior-level high pressure meetings”. The majority of the workshop is a task-force convened to address a simulated, but very realistic crisis event. In the class, each participant assumes a role, and is given about 30 minutes to prepare 1-2 slides. Once the class has prepared, the simulation begins. There is a role-play simulations. It is not uncommon to hear occasional “gasps” of disbelief from the participants. The workshop participants will thus experience rapid-fire questioning, interruption, and other situations that occur in senior-level meetings, but in a safe environment conducive to learning techniques for handling such situations.

Target audience: Technical Women who regularly attend technical meetings working groups and would like to develop and “command their presence” in high pressure meetings.

Panelists: Jessica Murillo, Steve Gordon, Ruchi Bhargava
schedule.title: Command Presence Workshop

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund. 

What you will learn:

  • Canonical's Openstack charms (e.g. core openstack, barbican, designate, etc.) 
  • Charming best practices (e.g. utilizing layering, reactive, contributing, git review process, etc.) which will be helpful as part of an Openstack Lifecycle, Operation, and Development.

*Actually, the first two aren’t guaranteed. AUC status, yes, and glitter. Lots of glitter.

schedule.description:
If you're new to OpenStack, this session is a great icebreaker and a way to get know new and experienced people in the OpenStack community. We plan to divide the session between career and technical mentoring. Mentees will be organized into small groups and each group will have several 15 minute mentoring sessions. In your small group, you'll get to know a bit about a mentor and have an opportunity to ask them a question or two about how you can grow your career, get involved in the community, and make the most of the summit. Then, at the end of 15 minutes, a new mentor will cycle to your group and the process will repeat.

If you're already a part of the OpenStack community, please consider signing up as a mentor. It's a wonderful way to meet new people, and pass on a bit of your knowledge about our community. Mentors will need to show up slightly earlier (by 7:15am, but breakfast is provided!). We will have a preparation call for mentors before the summit to go over what you should expect from the event.

More information about the Mentoring Program, sponsored by the Women of OpenStack, is available here. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Mentors
schedule.title: Speed Mentoring Organized by Women of OpenStack, Sponsored by Intel

videos.name: Speed Mentoring Organized by Women of OpenStack, Sponsored by Intel

schedule.description:
Whether you’re a big bank with big data, a media company delivering millions of streams, or a researcher studying billions of stars, OpenStack is the versatile, reliable platform for the work that matters.

 

Mark will explain how OpenStack’s “four opens” philosophy has been essential to achieving the rapid evolution of the platform, now capable of managing the bare metal, virtual machine, and container infrastructure today’s workloads need.
schedule.title: OpenStack for the Work that Matters

videos.name: OpenStack for the Work that Matters

schedule.description: Cloud is one of the pillars to support our Digital transformation. We decided to use Openstack as a technology enabler to build our Private Cloud capabilities, and to support Big Data and Real Time Analytics uses cases. Good engineering work has being done to adapt our Openstack Cloud to support these Big Data use cases. We have received some recognition for our Corporate Strategy in this area and Openstack has helped us to support it.
schedule.title: Big Data at Banco Santander

videos.name: Big Data at Banco Santander

schedule.description:
Sky, Europe’s leading entertainment company has standardized on OpenStack, which now powers 60 separate projects at Sky UK, ranging from Sky Tickets to the Sky Q set top box and their internal Video On Demand portal. With a customer OTT video platform generating billions of viewing records, the need to process store and move data has driven the growth of their OpenStack platform for Big Data analytics. Even their legacy enterprise apps, which are not suitable for cloud, are being monitored by the OpenStack based enterprise monitoring environment.

The OpenStack services behind all of these diverse workloads include Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, Keystone (integrated with Sky’s Active Directory), Designate, Swift, Heat, and Ceilometer (integrated with BMC). Looking toward the future, Matt will talk about their plans to upgrade to Mitaka and roll out Barbican, Magnum, and Trove to future automate key management, container orchestration, and databases.
schedule.title: Why Sky UK Runs on OpenStack

videos.name: Why Sky UK Runs on OpenStack

schedule.description: For the last 6+ years, OpenStack has evolved from being a "technology platform", to an "enterprise platform" (it's not perfect, but we're making huge progress). Now, it's time to think about using OpenStack in various industries, solving real world business problems. In this presentation, we will discuss how some of Huawei's customers in various industries (Telco, Government, Financial Services, Media, Automobile, etc) use OpenStack to innovate their business and capture the opportunities from today's fast growing digital economy.
schedule.title: Huawei Sponsor Keynote: Taking OpenStack to Industries

videos.name: Huawei Sponsor Keynote: Taking OpenStack to Industries

schedule.description: OPNFV Doctor and OpenStack Vitrage
schedule.title: Demo: OpenStack and OPNFV - Keeping Your Mobile Phone Calls Connected

videos.name: Demo: OpenStack and OPNFV - Keeping Your Mobile Phone Calls Connected

schedule.description: The growing influence and importance of OpenStack in the Cloud Computing market is undisputed. And the enormous support of hundreds of well known brands as well as a thriving community is no coincidence. The opportunity of shaping cloud infrastructure with this kind of flexibility is special. The Deutsche Telekom started supporting, promoting and working with this important initiative in 2012. The result of this collaboration is a perfect combination using the benefits of both sides. A multinational, flexible, affordable and secure public cloud: The OpenTelekomCloud - a unique offering throughout the cloud computing market that is pushing the boundaries of a large-scale public cloud helping to tighten OpenStack as Open Source Cloud Standard.
schedule.title: Deutsche Telekom Sponsor Keynote: DTAG: Unlocking the Public Cloud Potential of OpenStack

videos.name: Deutsche Telekom Sponsor Keynote: DTAG: Unlocking the Public Cloud Potential of OpenStack

schedule.description: Winners from the OpenStack Summit Austin, AT&T, will present the coveted award to an outstanding user in the OpenStack community.
schedule.title: Superuser Award

videos.name: Superuser Award

schedule.description: Scientific research has been one of the biggest use cases for OpenStack since its inception. In this session, we’ll catch up with one of the pioneers, Tim Bell from CERN who is running more than 190K OpenStack cores. His team is responsible for capturing, analyzing and storing data from the Large Hadron Collider.  The CERN team was the first OpenStack Superuser winner and continues to be strong contributors to the community. We’ll then shift gears to new research projects being built on OpenStack, including progressive translational medicine initiative at Cambridge University, correlating gene sequencing insights with clinical patient data to deliver real-time recommendations to doctors. We’ll also hear about the Sqaure Kilometer Array, a software defined telescope which will allow us to see deeper into space than ever before, exploring the origins of galaxy formation and dark matter, the nature of black holes and exploring fundamental building-blocks of life from extraterrestrial radio signals.
schedule.title: Smashing Particles, Revolutionizing Medicine and Exploring Origins of the Galaxy

videos.name: Smashing Particles, Revolutionizing Medicine and Exploring Origins of the Galaxy

schedule.description: Stretch your legs, grab a coffee, wander the Ramblas. Get your coffee on in the Marketplace!
schedule.title: Morning Break - 40 Min

schedule.description: Community Marketplace
schedule.title: Marketplace Open

schedule.description:
OpenStack has known scalability limitations and scaling beyond 100-200 compute nodes per single OpenStack instance (Region) is a challenge. Scaling out to support 500 + nodes in a single datacenter is possible by deploying multiple OpenStack instances in that location but that adds extra overhead, cost and management complexity for tenants.

In this case study, we will share our performance and scale test results, fine tuning that ‘worked’ versus ‘did not work’ to support the scale and the architecture changes made to OpenStack deployment to support 500+ compute nodes per OpenStack region.

We have addressed bottlenecks in the messaging bus, Nova scheduler, and other key components, with a combination of:
● Control plane flexibility (moving services to different hosts)
● Configuration changes particularly with RabbitMQ and Nova
● Tuning the use of Ceilometer
schedule.title: Scaling OpenStack to Support Large Scale Compute – 500 Computes and Beyond

schedule.description: An objective performance comparison of bare metal servers with servers used during Kolla scale testing. Operators should use this scale test of Kolla backed by real benchmark numbers in making the right choices for Operational Deployment Management (ODM).

slides.name: Achieving Significant Scale in Containerized OpenStack Deployments: Highlights learned from OSIC Scale Testing

schedule.title: Achieving Significant Scale in Containerized OpenStack Deployments: Highlights learned from OSIC Scale Testing

schedule.description: This live-demo will show how AppFormix makes OpenStack operations easy. AppFormix is next-generation monitoring for OpenStack services and the compute and storage infrastructure. Operators benefit from problem prediction using outlier detection and workload placement to resolve resource issues before users are impacted. Learn how advanced features like workload placement, capacity planning, and chargeback can simplify operations, improve ROI, and create a high-quality end-user experience.
schedule.title: AppFormix: OpenStack Operations Made Easy with AppFormix

videos.name: AppFormix: OpenStack Operations Made Easy with AppFormix

schedule.description:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-ops-haproxy-mysql-rabbit-tuning

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!
schedule.title: Ops: HAProxy, MySQL, Rabbit Tuning

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Concrete tips and tricks for doing DevOps and Continuous Delivery at various scales.

The importance of tools and processes, and the even greater importance of getting people to engage with them.
schedule.description:
SAP has been using a DevOps & Continuous Delivery approach for building its web and mobile apps for several years, and in the Cloud Infrastructure Service we are now building and running a global cloud at the scale needed to run not only SAP's internal business applications but also the cloud applications used by over 100 million people at SAP's 300,000 customers.

In this talk we tell the story of how SAP originally adopted DevOps practices with a simple pilot. That pilot included a bare-bones DevOps platform which evolved through several stages to become a next-generation open-source-based cloud and deployment automation system using OpenStack and Kubernetes.

At each stage of the journey we examine the technical and organisational challenges we faced and share how we overcame them. The most important lesson of all? Ultimately, it's about the people.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to implement and scale DevOps and Continuous Delivery practices from a single project to a global cloud.
schedule.title: SAP's DevOps Journey: From Building an App to Building a Cloud

videos.name: SAP's DevOps Journey: From Building an App to Building a Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: if you are a cloud administrator who wants to stand up murano to explore its features or a developer or who want to build your own application catalogs, you should come to this session. At the end of presetation, you should have a good understanding of how to get Murano running against your existing OpenStack in a few easy steps.
schedule.description:
We've all faced challenges in porting applications to run on OpenStack. Murano helps by enabling cloud admins to publish a well-tested set of on-demand and self-service applications. End users can simply use the applications.

But, have you ever wanted to set up Murano to explore its features, but been frustrated with putting all the required packages and their dependencies together and configure them correctly? Have you ever tried to build your own application catalog or create your own images, only to find out you are facing a steep learning curve.

In the presentation, we will demonstrate a simple end-to-end process for getting Murano running on your dev environment or your laptop by running Murano in Docker containers. We will also demonstrate the details in case you want to dive deep into Murano including configuring murano API server and engine, building your own application images and catalog, how to upload the application catalog and deploy them using cli or UI.
schedule.problem_addressed: Many cloud administrators and developers have encountered steep learning curves to get Murano started in their environment, and may get discouraged quickly. This presentation is an attempt to make it easier and help to get wider adoption for Murano.

slides.name: Hello World for Murano - End-to-End Process in a Docker Container and More

schedule.title: Hello World for Murano - End-to-End Process in a Docker Container and More

videos.name: Hello World for Murano - End-to-End Process in a Docker Container and More

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn valuable tips and take-away lessons on building PaaS and rolling it out in production.
schedule.description: Swisscom has one of the largest in-production industry standard Platform as a Service built on OpenStack. Their offering is focused on providing an enterprise-grade PaaS environment to customers worldwide and with various delivery models based on Cloud Foundry and OpenStack. Swisscom embarked early on the OpenStack journey to deploy their app cloud partnering with Red Hat, Cloud Foundry, and PLUMgrid. With services such as MongoDB, MariaDB, RabbitMQ, ELK, and an object storage, the PaaS cloud offers what developers need to get started right away. Join this panel for take-away lessons on Swisscom’s journey, the technologies, partnerships, and developers who are building apps everyday on Swisscom’s OpenStack cloud.
schedule.problem_addressed: This is based on a PaaS deployment that is in-production today.

slides.name: Deploying and Operating a Production Application Cloud with OpenStack

schedule.title: Deploying and Operating a Production Application Cloud with OpenStack

videos.name: Deploying and Operating a Production Application Cloud with OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the architecture of this cloud, how we leverage Ansible and Puppet to deploy and configure the cloud, how we manage upgrades, and how we leverage our code review-driven workflow to drive all of this.
schedule.description: The OpenStack Infrastructure team, made up of contributors from multiple companies, runs the systems that support the development, testing, and hosting of OpenStack and the services that support the OpenStack community. With donated hardware and datacenter space, the team runs a private OpenStack cloud to support its automated software testing infrastructure. InfraCloud, the project born out of increasing demand from our growing developer community and a desire to "dogfood" OpenStack, is managed in the same manner as the rest of our infrastructure -- as open source, review-driven configuration. Though we've long been consumers of OpenStack clouds, running one ourselves poses new and exciting challenges. This session will discuss how we use cloud technologies to tame our hardware and how we leverage our open source infrastructure to run a cloud.
schedule.problem_addressed: With donated hardware and datacenter space, we can run an optimized semi-private cloud for the purpose of adding testing capacity and also with an eye for “dog fooding” OpenStack itself.
schedule.title: InfraCloud, a Community Cloud Managed by the Project Infrastructure Team

videos.name: InfraCloud, a Community Cloud Managed by the Project Infrastructure Team

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the new Swift encryption feature, how it is enabled in deployment and gain an understanding of the security threats that it is intended to protect against.
schedule.description:
In the Newton cycle, Swift released an exciting new feature which enables encryption of object data at rest.

OpenStack Swift provides reliable and scalable object storage that has been deployed in many successful production environments. With the Newton release Swift has added an exciting new feature to enable encryption of object data on disks. This feature is intended to protect data at rest from an attacker that gains physical access to disks.

We will demonstrate this new feature, show how it is deployed, and discuss performance implications.

links.link: “Swift object encryption” preview presentation at Austin OpenStack Summit. https://www.openstack.org/summit/austin-2016/summit-schedule/events/6869

schedule.problem_addressed:
Object encryption addresses the security of data it at rest in Swift clusters. Unencrypted user data is at risk of exposure should a third party gain access to a disk.

Users can of course guard against this risk by encrypting data before sending to Swift, but often a server-side encryption service is desirable. This may be because operators themselves must ensure encryption of data at rest to satisfy regulatory and/or customer requirements, or because clients do not wish to manage encryption keys.

With this new feature Swift is able to encrypt objects as they are received through a Swift proxy. This has advantages over other server-side encryption approaches: encrypting content once in the proxy incurs lower CPU overhead than having each replica encrypted on object servers using existing block encryption tools such as dm-crypt; encrypting in Swift itself avoids the cost of upgrading hardware to self-encrypting disks.
schedule.title: New in Swift: Object Encryption

videos.name: New in Swift: Object Encryption

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will get the inside story on what it takes to operate a large public cloud. Hint: being systematic is extremely important! But this also means that this talk will be helpful if you’re operating a small private cloud, and you want to offer similar SLAs - perhaps the biggest difference is how often problems happen in the underlying fleet.

In particular, we will walk through some typical automation scenarios, such as applying an OpenStack Ansible security audit and remediation; Nova compute restarts; live migrations; storage capacity reallocations and the like. We will look at the opportunities in integrating with tooling like Walmart’s OneOps.

We also will talk about not only the strengths of Rackspace’s current solution, but also its weaknesses, such as being tightly coupled to Rackspace’s asset management system; and what prompted us to develop Craton as the next generation platform for fleet management.
schedule.description:
Use Rackspace’s proven approach for fleet management, with inventory and audit/remediation workflows. And stop spending your evenings and weekends to fix day-to-day operational issues in your OpenStack deployment! With the new Craton project, we may have new ops tools that can help you. Come see a presentation and demo of the Craton fleet management framework and working solution for OpenStack clouds, which we plan to become part of the OpenStack big tent.

Craton combines two key elements, while integrating with your existing environment. First, an inventory fabric to manage your inventory of hosts/devices, along with corresponding configuration variables; and the ability to wrap seamlessly existing inventory/asset management sources. Second, Craton enables running audit and remediation workflows across the fleet to help operate your cloud. Integration APIs complete the solution with other tooling you have in place, including CI/CD, governance, logging, monitoring, and alerting.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Craton is based on the fleet management solution currently in use to support Rackspace's public cloud. This existing solution has proven itself in production: it enables us to support such needs as live migrating the VMs on 19,000 hosts, or deploying the next release of OpenStack, with minimal manual remediation. We are able to carry out complex, multistage remediations based on Ansible.

Our approach is unique and operator-focused, with Craton building on a proven methodology for systematically managing a fleet of hosts/devices at scale. One example is audit: operators need to know what’s different about their environment - data that’s not necessarily captured by asset management; nor is it reported on by monitoring/metrics. Instead, we allow operators to craft their own audits, get results, and use that for their remediations. Consider this scenario: what should have been the same server builds had slightly different available memory to the OS; which in turn impacted migrations.
schedule.title: Simplify Day 2 Operations (And Get Some Sleep!) Through Craton Fleet Management

videos.name: Simplify Day 2 Operations (And Get Some Sleep!) Through Craton Fleet Management

schedule.description:
We build OpenStack because we know that cloud is the way of the future.  The days of "pets" are fading with every legacy application that gets broken up into containerized microservices.

So why are we still building OpenStack as a monolithic application that's upgraded every six months instead of applying changes and upgrades via CI/CD?

See how we’ve refactored the openstack-salt project to deliver containerized OpenStack services so that you can deploy and upgrade an entire cluster in less than 5 minutes. From seamless upgrades, patching and even rollbacks, discover our take on making OpenStack operationally manageable for the enterprise, coupling best-of-breed open source tooling with OpenStack projects to provide an experience that the enterprise has come to expect.

Learn about:

  • Containerizing OpenStack and OpenContrail SDN
  • Containers in production on Kubernetes with Calico.
  • HA for Kubernetes controllers, MySQL Galera in containers, RabbitMQ, etc.

Be blown away by live demos!

slides.name: Mirantis: Evolve or Die: Enterprise Ready OpenStack Upgrades with Kubernetes

schedule.title: Mirantis: Evolve or Die: Enterprise Ready OpenStack Upgrades with Kubernetes

videos.name: Mirantis: Evolve or Die: Enterprise Ready OpenStack Upgrades with Kubernetes

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should learn that there is more to implementing file systems for you application in the cloud than just attaching a block device to a compute node. And that as time moves forward we should all be thinking of ways to make use of Object storage and NoSQL solutions such as Redis/Mongo/Memcached.

We will also give some good operational guides on when to deploy GlusterFS, NFS, and/or DRBD and what are the gotchas and considerations.
schedule.description:
OpenStack has mature and powerful support for block storage devices. Allowing solutions architects to easily house traditional local file systems for data storage.

A busy cloud application at scale needs horizontal scalability and High Availability for all of the layers in the stack. This means Catalyst has been deploying a range of clustered file system solutions inside cloud platforms since 2012.

Catalyst have had exposture with NFS, OCFS2, DRBD, CEPH and GlusterFS. We will talk about our experiences here, especially with GlusterFS usage in anger.

In this presentation we will talk about the journey we are still on in finding the best fit for a file system inside a large fully-orchestrated cloud application stack.

We'll also socialising some mistakes that we think people making when choosing a file storage solution and remind everyone why clustered/networked file systems are a bit of a pain and why it makes sense to start thinking about object storage for more and more use cases.
schedule.problem_addressed:
We think that this presentation will be useful to all those wrestling with the architecture requirements of large traditional application stacks as they are moved into the cloud.

There are still plenty of operations people and solutions architects who are using OpenStack like VMware, without making use of any of the flexibility and power that a true infrastructure-as-a-service offering gives you. With the ability to build better resilience to failure and have flexible, responsive resource usage based on load and performance requirements.

We will also discuss solutions to some of the common problems with tradition filesystem solutions such as: capacity planning, high availability architecture, automated failover, and backup strategies to maximise data retention.
schedule.title: Clustered File Systems in Your Application Stack

videos.name: Clustered File Systems in Your Application Stack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about more effective ways to be integrated into the OpenStack decision making and major technology develop directions and processes. Attendees will also have an opportunity to provide feedback to the Foundation & Community on how we can work together to make OpenStack a true global movement
schedule.description:
Most of the OpenStack project, workgroup, and comittee meetings are happening in US or during US working hours. As someone who lives outside of US, how do I keep up with the latest development of OpenStack, and effectively contribute and collaborate with other OpenStack developers and members?

In this panel, we will have non-US managers and developers who will share their challenges, experiences, and learnings to be integrated into the OpenStack community, and to be a significant contributer to OpenStack. Also, we will brainstorm on ideas on how we can make OpenStack a true global movement.
schedule.problem_addressed: As OpenStack is moving toward the global market, we will have more and more non-US OpenStack users and develoeprs. However due to the languague, time zone, and location barriers, many non-US OpenStack members face challenges in getting truly integrated into the OpenStack core decision making processes and technical development directions. Our goal for this panel is to share and brainstorm on ideas to make OpenStack a true global movement that regardless where you are live, you can still make a difference in the OpenStack community and ecosystem.
schedule.title: If I Don't Live in US, How Do I Become a Significant Contributor to OpenStack?

videos.name: If I Don't Live in US, How Do I Become a Significant Contributor to OpenStack?

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!

 

About this session

  • Hyperconverged vs Converged vs Disaggregated
  • Should OpenStack manage physical HW for Converged/Hyperconverged systems
  • How to manage HW inventory and link them to OpenStack services (dependencies, etc.)
  • OCP
  • Rack scale?
  • Network scale? (Spine switches, Datacenter configurations, multi-site connectivity)
  • Capacity planning
  • commercial considerations - approaches to modelling the costs
schedule.title: Ops: Hardware

schedule.description:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-ops-migration-to-OpenStack

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!
schedule.title: Ops: Migration to OpenStack

schedule.description:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-ops-security

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!

 

Discussion topics
  • Keystone and experience with Fernet
  • API abstraction / inspection with mod_security
  • General defence - rate limiting etc.
  • DDOS strategies
  • Managing and using policy.json with custom roles etc.
  • What other roles do we need for Operations besides Administrator and normal Tenants?
schedule.title: Ops: Security

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How Designate should be set up for each cloud, and what benfits you can offer your end users.
schedule.description:
In this presentation, Graham Hayes and Kiall Mac Innes will show the a few of the different options for deploying Designate, and how it can fit into different uses cases, including Public Cloud, and different types of public cloud setups.

Graham and Kiall have both ran Designate as a public cloud service, and have produced productised versions of Designate for use in private clouds.

We will highlight the benifits for end users, using tools like Heat, python bindings, Shade and Ansible and others, and how this also benifits Cloud Operators in both private and public clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed: How Designate can offer more than just an easy API / UI for DNS changes in an OpenStack cloud, and how as an operator, you can enable your users to do more.
schedule.title: Designate - The "Why" and the "How"

videos.name: Designate - The "Why" and the "How"

schedule.description:
The Large Deployments team is a group of Operators running large clouds, or many clouds, that works with the various dev teams on common issues with running OpenStack at scale.  The team has been meeting since the Paris summit.  

 

Based on how things went in Austin, we'd like to try having a session early on that we can sit down at the begginning of the summit, identify sessions we would like LDT members in and plan how best to take the needs of the team to them.  I'll submit a follow up request for time on Friday that we can regroup and go over everything that we worked with developers and other teams before we leave Barcelona
schedule.title: Large Deployment Team - Planning the Week

schedule.description: Is this your first OpenStack Design Summit? Unlike most conferences, you are invited to participate and play an active role. But... where to start? The rationale and the organization that allows such a unique collaborative design will be explained. This is your chance to get answers and get the best of it!During this session we will let the attendants know some details about the Design Summit, including who will be attending, different tracks and purposes, which sessions/talks are the most suitable for beginners and how they can participate. This short introduction will be followed by a lively presentation of the most common situations and how to behave when facing them. It will be a miniature experience of a first participation to the Design Summit.
schedule.title: Design Summit 101

schedule.description: The App Ecosystem Working group is planning to join forces with the App Hackathon WG and ISV Interop (Enterprise WG) and other WGs/teams targeted to enable app developers on OpenStack. This working session will be used to define a umbrella structure, mission and unified goals for the next cycle.
schedule.title: App Developer Enabling

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can take away practical lessons and advice as newcomers to the OpenStack community in a technical role.
schedule.description:
Almost one year ago, I joined the Boston-based team at Tesora. Having no previous experience working hands-on with the OpenStack community, the past year has been a learning experience riddled with many challenges and triumphs.

Tesora’s Database as a Service (DBaaS) Platform runs on OpenStack Trove, the OpenStack DBaaS offering.  I joined Tesora as a QA Engineer, and have learned many lessons over the past several months.

This talk will highlight:

  • The biggest challenges faced coming into the OpenStack community
  • The challenges of navigating OpenStack documentation
  • Making sense of a complicated software ecosystem
  • Insight on the OpenStack community & how to become involved

Whether it's attending my first Summit or diving head-first into OpenStack documentation, I've learned several important lessons to navigating the OpenStack community and believe others just starting out in their journey may benefit from a candid discussion.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session will address what new members of the OpenStack community can expect when beginning their OpenStack journey and how to navigate a complicated software ecosystem.
schedule.title: Working on OpenStack: My First Year in the Community

videos.name: Working on OpenStack: My First Year in the Community

schedule.description: With test driven development, continuous integration/continuous deployment and devops practices now the norm, most organizations understand the importance of testing their applications. But what about the cloud those applications are going to live on? Too many companies miss this critical step, leading to gaps in their operations, which can lead to production issues, API outages, inability to upgrade, and general instability of the cloud. It all begs the question: “Do you even test? During this session, attendees will learn how Rackspace leverages Red Hat’s Distributed Continuous Integration (DCI) to build a better OpenStack experience for their customers while reducing the time required to not only roll out the latest version of OpenStack to new customers, but also begin upgrading customers within weeks of announcement. In addition to this, the automated testing in DCI raises bugs directly with Red Hat QAs team to shorten the feedback cycle and improve the final product.
schedule.title: Red Hat: Leveraging CI/CD to Improve OpenStack Operations

videos.name: Red Hat: Leveraging CI/CD to Improve OpenStack Operations

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to gain knowledge on how and under what principals a bank or finance institute can use compliant IaaS cloud based on OpenStack and what they should demand from a cloud provider to meet their specific requirements. We will also show how Folksam use automation and continous deployments for thier environments with ansible and gigaspaces. So this will both a presentation covering both the legall fundamentals of providing compliant IaaS clouds as well as a practical part covering how Folksam utilize OpenStack for their needs.
schedule.description:
Presenters are Daniel Gustafsson VP-BU-Compliant Cloud at City Network and Roger Ewert IT area architect for Technology and Infrastructure at Folksam

Late 2015 City Network launched a initiative to build IaaS clouds based on OpenStack for regulated industries with a heavy focus on Bank and Finance. Insurance company Folksam was one of the first customers that started using the servcice. Folksam wanted to change the way the ran thier applications and services. They wanted be able to have a scaleable platform that could easily be deployed thru automation tools like ansible and function with contionues deployments. In this presentation we will cover how this was acomplished.
schedule.problem_addressed: The use case is how OpenStack can be used for compliant clouds for bank and finance companies, in this case with the focus on the insureance industry. We will adress how City Network used OpenStack to meet Folksams technical demands for automation, continous deployment and a pay as you go pricemodel but at the same time fulfill the regulatory demands Folksam live under. All the way from local Swedish governance rules to EU Solvency directives. As it stands right now City Network is the only provider in Europe who have a pay as you go model IaaS cloud based on OpenStack that can meet these requirements. This is the story on how we did it and how Folksam who was our launch customer utilize it.
schedule.title: Why Insurance Company Folksam Chose City Network OpenStack Laas Cloud for Finance and Insurance

videos.name: Why Insurance Company Folksam Chose City Network OpenStack Laas Cloud for Finance and Insurance

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees are expected to learn about Docker latest release, Docker Swarm orchestration, distributed Key/Value store like Etcd, Docker networking primitives, how Kuryr plugs into Docker, how Kuryr works and leverages OpenStack Neutron. Attendees will learn to use, deploy, hack and debug Docker, Etcd, Kuryr and Neutron.
The hands-on workshop will enable operators and developers to have a decent understanding of all the components above by the end of the session.
schedule.description:
Microservices architectures are revolutionizing the way software is envisioned and built. OpenStack has started to play a key role in enabling the microservices architectures and focused groups inside OpenStack community are working towards this goal: Magnum, Kuryr etc.
Docker is one of the key components here and combining them all, we get to build microservices architectures using tools like Docker Swarm, Etcd, Kuryr and Neutron. This workshop will provide attendees with the opportunity to gain experience with various Docker features and uses cases integrated with the OpenStack ecosystem. The lab will cover wide range of topics:

Introduction to Docker and OpenStack
Docker Swarm: Architecture and usage
Etcd
Kuryr and Neutron: Architecture and usage with DevStack
Deploying Microservices
Breaking Docker, Kuryr and debugging it!

Attendees simply need to come in (with their laptop). Workshop speaker/organizer will provide instructions and will be available to answer any questions.

links.link: Networking For Nested Containers Magnum, Kuryr, Neutron Integration [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=00vo2FtY54Q]
Docker Networking in Docker Swarm, Mesos and Kubernetes [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1A-ZDNcyKu0]
Docker Networking in the OpenStack World [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=crVi30bgOt0]

schedule.problem_addressed: Microservices architectures and tools used to build them are fairly new to the OpenStack users and some of the areas in this technology space have made great progress in recent weeks and continues to evolve very fast. Being a developer on these technologies and having the knowledge about the up to date progress, the goal is this session to share the latest and greatest in the space of Docker and OpenStack to enable microservices architectures.
schedule.title: Hands-On Workshop: Learn About Microservices Architectures with Docker Swarm, Etcd, Kuryr, Neutron

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will first learn the history of Linux encryption methods including filesystem and block device level encryption.  Attendees will then explore the potential security vulnerabilities of using unencrypted Cinder storage and how one can easily configure Cinder to utilize dm-crypt and the Linux Unified Key Setup-on-disk-format (LUKS) for block device level encryption.  Participants will not only setup Cinder with encryption, but create both encrypted and unencrypted volumes, attach these volumes to Nova instances, and even replicate a real-world bare-metal attack by attempting to recover OpenStack user data!
schedule.description: We all know Cinder provides the awesome ability to attach block storage to our Nova instances but how secure is the data we place on these volumes? Join us as we explore the potential security vulnerabilities in using unencrypted Cinder storage and setup a live OpenStack environment to utilize block device level encryption.  Participants will learn the history of Linux encryption methods and how Cinder can utilize these methods to securely write data to block volumes.  All participants will receive a live OpenStack environment and step-by-step instruction on the Linux packages and OpenStack configuration files necessary to implement a secure Cinder infrastructure.  After completing the workshop,  participants walk away with peace of mind when faced with the possibility of bare-metal attacks on their OpenStack environment!
schedule.problem_addressed: Although there are always a variety of Cinder presentations on complex use-cases and deployments, very few talk about the necessity of encrypting Cinder volumes.  Because OpenStack adoption is on the rise and the threat of bare-metal attacks on OpenStack environments is higher, encrypting sensitive data written to Cinder volumes is more important than ever.  Rackspace Training Summit Workshops are the first to provide large audiences with easily accessible environments, dynamic slide content, and truly effective instruction that takes learning OpenStack to the next level.
schedule.title: Secure Your Cinder: A Hands-On Workshop with Cinder Encryption

schedule.description:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-ops-nova (double session)

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!"

About this session
Real Live Nova developer and core reviewer John Garbutt is very interested in how you use nova. He comes armed with a list of questions from the developers on things that they'd like to know, but a good chunk of the session is for your feedback. Bring bug links and error logs!!
schedule.title: Ops: Nova

schedule.description:
RSVP REQUIRED: http://mirantistuesdaytraining.eventbrite.com

This training is one full day, all day Tuesday, October 25th. 
Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This one day introduction course covers business perspectives and basics of OpenStack. The course is intended for project managers, business developers, and sales engineers who desire high level understanding of OpenStack components and operations. The course is broken up into lectures and labs. During lectures students will learn basics of cloud computing, OpenStack business values, its overview, and the ecosystem. The labs will provide hands-on experience using the Horizon dashboard to provision cloud resources like virtual machines, virtual networks, and block storage, as well as manage VM images.
schedule.title: RSVP Required: Mirantis One-Day Training - OpenStack Fundamentals

schedule.description:
The OpenStack UX project will be conducting a series of ten usability studies to identity both opportunities and pain points associated with completing common tasks using the OpenStack Common Client (OSC).  Please reach-out to the OpenStack UX project if you would like to participate in the study.  

A link will be provided on the OpenStack UX wiki if you’re an operator and would like to schedule a time to participate in the study.
schedule.title: Help Improve OpenStack! Participate in the Common Client (OSC) Usability Study with Operators

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this talk we will cover trends, challenges, opportunities with different IoT architectural (centralized, decentralized) models and will discuss various issues and nuances associated with openstack swift serving IoT workload and presents features, approaches to solve them by leveraging an unified clustered file and object storage architecture.
schedule.description:
With the immense growth of connected devices across multiple industry verticals in recent times, Internet of Things (IoT) platforms gained huge focus across various organisations. As volume, velocity of data generated by the IoT devices are massive, there exists a need for scalable, faster, analytic, internet friendly storage. Even though we are in early stages of IoT wave there exists multiple frameworks (centralized vs. decentalized), prototypes in market today. However with the maturity of IoT workloads, openstack swift architecture as a sole does not meet the growing requirements of IoT data.

The proposed presentation discusses in detail various design issues and nuances associated with object storage serving IoT workload and presents different features, approaches to solve them by leveraging a massively scalable, parallel, n unified clustered file and object storage architecture.
schedule.problem_addressed: As the adoption of IoT increases, current object storage architecture as a sole does not meet the growing requirements of IoT data. In order to meet the current, future demands of IoT data, there exists a need to build an eco system storage architecture which helps in facilitating compatibility between M2M (Machine to Machine), REST protocols, end user controllable privacy policies for storage, support for in place analytics, even notification based information life cycle management, auto notification from storage to end devices etc.
schedule.title: Beyond Object Storage - A Unified Storage Architecture for IoT

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• An overview of how notification and remediation approaches can help ease the operational management of the different NFV resources.
  • How to specify notification and remediation measures for VNF resources in TOSCA VNFD templates
  • How Tacker handles notifications and remediations
schedule.description:
The advent of NFV has changed the way TELCOs are beginning to deploy network functions. NFV has brought benefits in terms of deployment agility and cost reduction while also introducing virtualization layers that add complexity and operational challenges. One of the critical requirement for TELCO to maintain SLA is that identifying the abnormal situations of running VNFs and address them to bring it to normal operational state,  automatically or manually. This requires monitoring, async event notifications, remediation such as scaling which has been addressed collectively by OpenStack services tacker, ceilometer, heat, etc...

In this session, we will discuss in detail about these features and how OSS can use them automatically to handle the abnormal situations.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• How to provide notification of NFV resources events
  • How to provide remediation  such as scale-out of running VNFs and make it resilient
  • How to monitor the running NFV resources.
schedule.title: Meeting SLA: NFV Notification and Remediation Using Tacker

schedule.description:
OpenStack is the ideal platform for the development of new cloud-native workloads and DevOps. However, more and more enterprise users also see huge potential in OpenStack to help drive efficiency improvements, increase productivity and lower costs in their existing traditional datacenters.
Join us to discuss how OpenStack can expand and evolve the abilities of existing infrastructure and free IT to be more active in experimenting with new revolutionary technologies and applications. We will also explore specific tools to help enhance your OpenStack experience and smooth the transition to a new way of getting things done.
schedule.title: SUSE: Delivering Full Value of OpenStack - Mixing Evolution with Revolution

videos.name: SUSE: Delivering Full Value of OpenStack - Mixing Evolution with Revolution

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this talk, we will provide an overview the of OpenStack storage components, and the benefits generally provided with shared filesystem storage. We will provide a detailed review of the features that Spectrum Scale provides and explain the benefits these can bring to your OpenStack cloud.
schedule.description: Efficient data storage is critical for large scale OpenStack cloud deployments. There are several shared file systems that can be used in an OpenStack cloud. These can be used to efficiently share data between Nova, Glance and Cinder, as well as provide storage for object and file based protocols with Swift and Manila. Enterprise features like copy on write file clones and file system snapshots, policy based tiering of data between storage classes, and intelligent backup schemes are important benefits that the filesystem backend can provide. In this presentation we describe these benefits that a shared file system can bring to your cloud architecture.
schedule.problem_addressed: Having different backend storages for multiple components in an OpenStack cloud can be cumbersome job for managing storage. Using shared filesystem can effiectively share data between OpenStack components giving the benefit of having the storage under the same umbrella. This storage can be effectively used and accessed though OpenStack components using different protocols and also adds benefit of managing it easily.
schedule.title: Sharing - What's True Since Childhood is True for Clouds! Using Shared Filesystem in OpenStack Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Data management between OpenStack environments, on premsise storage and public cloud.
schedule.description: Hybrid cloud environments are real now. Enterprises are no longer always sticking to a single cloud, they are opting for a hybrid approach of having a OpenStack private cloud and one or more public clouds. In this session we will showcase the scalable Veritas NAS solution that can manage data present in OpenStack but also provide for a bridge for moving the data back and forth seamlessly between other private/public clouds
schedule.problem_addressed: On how global name space can be achieved between OpenStack, on-premise and public cloud
schedule.title: Enabling Policy Based Seamless Data Movement Between OpenStack and Private/Public Clouds

schedule.description: OpenStack is enterprise approved. Large companies run applications that generate billions in revenue on top of OpenStack. With the added complexity of now being also responsible for what’s going on under the hood in the cloud platform, it’s getting even more important to have a holistic, clear picture of the health of your application, the underlying infrastructure, as well as the end-user experience. We know that bad application performance is directly related to declining revenue. Can you tell the difference between bad performance of an application and bad performance of a cloud platform, like OpenStack? Both now and in the future application monitoring is going to be a key element. Providing good end user experience will be a deciding factor if your business is successful or not, and the performance of the underlying cloud platform provides a significant contribution. To that end, you need to have monitoring in place that provides insights into OpenStack’s internals and can correlate events from the control plane with events of your applications.
schedule.title: Dynatrace: How Monitoring OpenStack can Help Maintaining a Healthy Work-Life Balance

videos.name: Dynatrace: How Monitoring OpenStack can Help Maintaining a Healthy Work-Life Balance

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: As OpenStack evolves from serving the development community to hosting production workloads, management reporting and planning requirements have to evolve as well. This talk will be a journey and will focus on lessons learned and best practices from a production OpenStack deployment at scale.
schedule.description:
Verizon Wireless is using OpenStack as the basis for the Verizon Cloud Platform (VCP).  Openstack is helping bring features to customers faster, allowing the business to be more responsive to internal requests for services and to deliver innovative solutions to enterprise customers.  Workloads extend far beyond Infrastructure as a Service to also include networking products, databases, data-stores, hosted applications and more.    VCP services are delivered by a federated group of datacenters distributed globally.

Verizon will share lessons learned from deploying and operating early phases of the Verizon Cloud Platform - an OpenStack cloud.

links.link: http://www.openstackeast.com/ - we are presenting this in New York in August, but the session URL is not yet available.

schedule.problem_addressed:
The management and usability requirements for a private cloud of this scope are complex.  Stakeholders for this project include all lines of business, internal and external developers, and external customers as well.  Each of the stakeholders are interested in varying metrics but all require accurate reporting to track service delivery progress. 

  • Project owners need to understand their real-time consumption of VCP services and the financial impact to their budgets.
  • Operators need capacity data to maintain appropriate utilization in support of capacity growth needs.
  • Executives need to demonstrate that VCP is meeting cost and service level objectives while supporting budgetary requirements.
schedule.title: OpenStack Management at Hyperscale – A Verizon Case Study

videos.name: OpenStack Management at Hyperscale – A Verizon Case Study

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about all the various facets of the OpenStack complex polyhedron. At the end of this session, they will be able to answer confidently (if not succintly) the most asked question in the world of OpenStack.
schedule.description:
"What is OpenStack ?" is easily the most common question we receive. And yet our most common answer still is "well, it's complicated". OpenStack is a lot of different things to a lot of different people. Is it a common goal, a bunch of Python code, a single product, a set of disconnected projects, a job market, an interoperable standard, a community, a set of principles, a social experiment ?

In this talk, Thierry Carrez, Director of Engineering at the OpenStack Foundation and chair of the OpenStack Technical Committee, draws on the past 6 years of academic research on that question to deliver the final, ultimate and complete answer.
schedule.problem_addressed: Confusion about what OpenStack is (and what it is not) is one of the top issues encountered by newcomers to our community, and it still bites experienced members as well. This talk will hopefully shine a new light on this complex question and clear up a number of misunderstandings.

slides.name: What is OpenStack? The Comprehensive Answer

schedule.title: What is OpenStack? The Comprehensive Answer

videos.name: What is OpenStack? The Comprehensive Answer

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: DreamHost team will unashamedly share the horror stories in its development, operations and procurement so that no other cloud operator will have to suffer in the same way.
schedule.description: When DreamHost started developing, deploying and selling cloud services in 2011, the team embarked in a life-long learning effort, full of obstacles and with the promise of a wonderful destination. DreamHost ventured in uncharted territory betting on young and promising open source technologies: OpenStack, and Ceph. Observed from the distance, DreamObjects and DreamCompute appear as mature products powered by solid Continuous Integration and Deployment, leveraging Chef, Jenkins, Jenkins Job Builder, and fpm. But looking back at the journey log, DreamHost team has collected lots of stories to tell: there was a time when we had to summon dozens of engineers from 4 companies to debug crashing SSD disks; and another time when our TechOps folks had to defeat snow blizzards. Pioneers’ trips are never easy but their stories are rewarding. Join this session to learn how DreamHost team has architected OpenStack, Ceph and Neutron to power the DreamHost Cloud products.
schedule.problem_addressed: Help operators understand what mistakes to avoid while planning for large deployments of OpenStack, Ceph and Astara. DreamHost is proud to share its embarrassing moments and the decisions that proved to be right.
schedule.title: Deploying OpenStack with Neutron and Ceph: From Concept to Public Cloud (and Hell in the Middle)

videos.name: Deploying OpenStack with Neutron and Ceph: From Concept to Public Cloud (and Hell in the Middle)

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn the service edge routers and how virtualizing the functions through vPE could add greater flexibility, service richness, and faster time to market.
schedule.description:
vCPE (Virtualized Customer Premise Equipment) and vPE (Virtualized Provider Edge) promises greater service agility, lower cost, and faster time to market for business and residential services deployments. Service edge routers or provider edge routers deliver business, residential and mobile subscriber services with functions such as BNG, BGP VPNs and Evolved Packet Cores. With the advent of NFV many of these services can be disaggregated and provided through modular virtual network functions with service function chaining which offers great flexibility to compose, deploy and automate services. These can be used to deliver a rich vCPE services such as triple play and IoT to residential and SMB customers while using the virtualized edge routers to provide core business services.

Service Providers are exploring methods 
In this talk, Principal architects will share considerations in designing virtual infrastructure to deliver vCPE and vPE based services. The speakers will provide some background on service function chaining, service edge routing, Openstack clouds and discuss virtualized architectures that can solve Service Provider problems to achieve agility and richness of cloud based services
schedule.problem_addressed: vPE is a key NFV use case that is a critical function in any service provider’s network since it provides business, residential, and mobile services. This session addresses virtualizing the edge router services and leverage OpenStack to provide the cloud environments.

slides.description:
vCPE (Virtualized Customer Premise Equipment) and vPE (Virtualized Provider Edge) promises greater service agility, lower cost, and faster time to market for business and residential services deployments. Service edge routers or provider edge routers deliver business, residential and mobile subscriber services with functions such as BNG, BGP VPNs and Evolved Packet Cores. With the advent of NFV many of these services can be disaggregated and provided through modular virtual network functions with service function chaining which offers great flexibility to compose, deploy and automate services. These can be used to deliver a rich vCPE services such as triple play and IoT to residential and SMB customers while using the virtualized edge routers to provide core business services.

Service Providers are exploring methods 
In this talk, Principal architects will share considerations in designing virtual infrastructure to deliver vCPE and vPE based services. The speakers will provide some background on service function chaining, service edge routing, Openstack clouds and discuss virtualized architectures that can solve Service Provider problems to achieve agility and richness of cloud based services
slides.name: Slides

schedule.title: Delivering Composable NFV Services for Business, Residential and Mobile Edge

videos.name: Delivering Composable NFV Services for Business, Residential and Mobile Edge

schedule.description: Currently OpenStack is becoming de-facto standard cloud platform for telecom operators, and many of them start utilizing OpenStack in their environment. NEC has been supporting their activities for several years, and understand their requirements for OpenStack. In the session, we summarize the requirements and introduce our latest solution for that. And especially we pick the operation costs of Day2 that means after set up the environment. It is currently big burden for many operators. In the second part of the session, we will introduce our customers challenge and R&D activities about efficient and intelligent distributed monitoring framework for Day 2 operation.
schedule.title: NEC: The Telecom Requirements for OpenStack: How to Reduce Operation Cost After Day 2

videos.name: NEC: The Telecom Requirements for OpenStack: How to Reduce Operation Cost After Day 2

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to build heterogeneous environment with shared Horizon and Keystone
  • How to integrate non-x86 servers into your OpenStack environment
  • How to model complex applications build using legacy enterprise software and publish it to your Murano app catalog
  • How to make a diverse OpenStack deployment repeatable using Fuel plugins
  • How to make it agile with undercloud / overcloud approach
  • How to keep such a project manageable with limited resources and strict schedule
schedule.description:
Being the largest bank in Central and Eastern Europe and the only Russian bank featuring in the World's Top 50 Biggest Banks, Sberbank operates a diverse set of business critical applications hosted on heterogeneous x86 / RISC infrastructure and needs to update them much faster than ever to keep ahead of the game.

On its journey towards becoming a true Agile Enterprise, Sberbank has chosen OpenStack and Murano to speed up provisioning of complex multi-tier applications spread across KVM, VMware vSphere, MS Hyper-V, IBM PowerVM and Oracle SPARC virtual machines as well as bare-metal servers for 6500+ in-house developers and QA engineers.

This session will provide some details on architectural decisions, trade-offs and lessons learned while designing and building such a complex OpenStack environment.
schedule.problem_addressed:
This session is intended to address an unsurprisingly common (and yet to be solved) problem of every large enterprise trying to adopt OpenStack: how to make OpenStack friends with complex multi-tier applications built using legacy technologies. Speaking of banks, these applications are often hosted on UNIX (AIX / Solaris) servers adding another layer of complexity.

This session will provide some lessons learned from the field on how this use case could be addressed using multi-region undercloud/overcloud OpenStack deployment and extra capabilities provided by OpenStack Fuel and Murano projects.
schedule.title: OpenStack: You Can Take It to the Bank!

videos.name: OpenStack: You Can Take It to the Bank!

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
* Scalability limits of vanilla OpenStack with increasing number of compute nodes.

* Methodology / tools to benchmark OpenStack deployment.

* Default settings vs tuned settings (if required).
schedule.description: Performance working group is working on identifying best OpenStack performance verification since Mitaka, and this session is about one of our researches done during Newton release cycle. This research is targeting on how evaluating OpenStack workability and performance at large scale. In particular, we will discuss in this presentation 1000 nodes cloud emulation testing on top of two different testbeds. Scripts that have been used to perform those tests are freely available so that anyone can evaluate the performance of an OpenStack deployment either on different hardware as well as software parameters.
schedule.problem_addressed: While OpenStack is becoming more and more robust, the performance/scalability of the system is often debated. However, there is no concrete study that cleary shows the limits of the system and what are the major bottlenecks that should be addressed for the next releases. In this presentation, we will present a reproducible way to evaluate the performance of an openstack deployment with a particular focus on the Nova component. This methodology used Rally to evaluate different containerized OpenStack deployments and see for instance whether a new feature/release improves the scalability criteria. To illustrate the advantages of such a methodology, we will describe a thousand-nodes scenario that has been evaluated on two different platforms (ie., Grid'5000 and Mirantis testing lab). In particular, we will discuss whether the performance trends that have been collected by the Inria team on one side and Mirantis on the other side are similar.
schedule.title: Chasing 1000 Nodes Scale

videos.name: Chasing 1000 Nodes Scale

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should learn about existing solutions for online schema upgrades in Openstack projects like keystone, glance and neutron. Also, listeners will get to know the proposed improvements in upgrade process.
schedule.description: Reliable Openstack deployment should be as close to 100% availability as possible and always up to date with the latest release. To achieve this, during an upgrade services should be stopped and replaced with new one with no API downtime. In projects like keystone, glance or neutron this means keeping compatibility of DB schema between releases. The complexity of maintaining this compatibility, while keeping performance and security on a high level, is a hot topic in the community. Current approach in projects like nova or cinder requires keeping the data compatibility for 2 or 3 releases. In this presentation we want to show solutions, how to reduce the data migration time period to one release cycle. This would reduce the code complexity and performance overhead in database layer.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session address the rolling upgrades approach and improving the already existing mechanism for schema rolling upgrades. It elaborates the current status in glance, keystone and neutron projects and will introduce the improvements in process.
schedule.title: Perform Schema Rolling Upgrades in Just One Release Cycle

videos.name: Perform Schema Rolling Upgrades in Just One Release Cycle

schedule.description:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-ops-logging-monitoring

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Tools and War Stories tracks of the conference will be much more friendly!

 

About this session
OpenStack deployments are complex to maintain. There are thousands of variables and dozens of services in multiple possible topologies. As Operators we are the first line of defense when issues start to creep out in production. In this session we will discuss the mechanisms available to alert Operators when a problem occurs or when metrics/trends signal that the environment is not in optimal condition anymore. We will discuss how data can be collected in different forms - logs, events, checks, etc. - and what are the most popular and effective tools being used by our community. In addition we will discuss what are the advantages/disadvantages of these open tools when we compare existing OpenStack projects such as Ceilometer/Aodh/Gnocci & Monasca. In addition we will identify what content (plugins, filters, visualizations, etc.) associated to these tools is already available and shared in open source and what are best options for reuse & associated best practices. Participants are expected to share their latest developments in this important Operational area.
 
Some popular tools we would like to discuss are:
 
  • ELK (ElasticSearch, Logstash & Kibana)
  • Nagios, Icinga, Sensu, Zabbix, etc.
  • Graphite/Collectd, Influx/Telegraf, Ganglia, Grafana, etc.
  • Intersection with existing OpenStack projects
 
Lastly, we will try to make sense of the vast proliferation of monitoring tools and what are their pros and cons for different usage scenarios.
schedule.title: Ops: Logging and Monitoring

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee's Ops Meetups Team, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. About this session
 This session is to disucss Telecom/NFV specific issues/usecases/best practices.
 The goal is to find the common action items and do some work together.
 
Discussion:

  • Issues/pain points for telcos. What need fix?

  • Tacker
  • Gluon - Bun Hu
  • What can this WG do to OpenStack?
  • write user stories?
  • upstream?
