schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Existing OpenStack projects and solutions about hybrid cloud.
  • Best practice for operators from hybrid cloud point of view.
  • Real life use cases of hybrid cloud in China.
schedule.description:
Companies are on longer asking if they should move to the cloud. They’re asking how to migrate to hybrid cloud with OpenStack. A hybrid cloud can offer a company the best of both public and private cloud, meet the requirements such as Cloud bursting, Disaster Recovery, Lifecycle-based Deployment, etc. But not if you slip into one of these pitfalls.

  • Visibility: how to manage clouds with a single pane?
  • Access Control: how to handle different credentials with security manner?
  • Network Connectivity: how to manage network configurations and maintain connectivity across clouds?
  • Outage & DR: how to ensure hybrid applications stay up during one cloud outages?
  • Audit & Compliance: how to collect audit data and comply with regulations?

Some OpenStack projects/features like tacker, tricircle, freezer, federated identity, sso, etc have collaborated to address these problems. In this session, I’ll share:

  • The pitfalls in OpenStack
  • What are different teams working on
  • Solutions and mitigations
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Best Practice when migrating to hybrid cloud with OpenStack
  • Disaster recovery in hybrid cloud context
  • Deploying and operating hybrid cloud

slides.name: Beware the Pitfalls When Migrating to Hybrid Cloud with OpenStack

schedule.title: Beware the Pitfalls When Migrating to Hybrid Cloud with OpenStack

videos.name: Beware the Pitfalls When Migrating to Hybrid Cloud with OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees of this session will:

  • Learn about the AUC program and its relationship to the User Committee
  • Identify ways they can contribute to the community as an AUC
  • What this means for the OpenStack community going forward
schedule.description:
The AUC recognition working group spent the last release cycle working with multiple groups within the OpenStack community including the User Committee and the OpenStack Foundation to help expand the definition of contributions beyond the current definition of only code or technical contributions.

The Working Group chairs will share with the participants the following topics:

  • How the effort started, why and AUC, some history and background
  • Which community roles are considered eligible for AUC. How the criteria were decided.
  • How you can get involved in the community as an AUC!
  • Next steps for the AUC program and its relationship with the User Committee.
schedule.problem_addressed: The AUC (Active User Contributor) is a newly created designation to recognize and promote community contributions that help foster growth for OpenStack as a platform and community.  We intend to share details about this newly created program and also how to get involved in the community and become an AUC yourself.
schedule.title: The Path to Becoming an AUC (Active User Contributor)

videos.name: The Path to Becoming an AUC (Active User Contributor)

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: We'll share not only our success stories, but also plenty of harrowing and humbling lessons we've learned the hard way that we think every Swift operator should know -- ranging across development, testing, deployment, operations, and monitoring.
schedule.description:
Come hear IBM SoftLayer's OpenStack Swift story and lessons from operating public object storage.

IBM's SoftLayer began its OpenStack journey in early 2012 when it launched public OpenStack Swift clusters in three of its global datacenters. Over the last 4.5 years, it has added Swift clusters into 22 additional datacenters at break-neck pace, launched several multi-facility Swift clusters, and expanded global storage capacity by several orders of magnitude. Join us for this session as we share the story of our journey running Swift at scale over the years.
schedule.problem_addressed: Fast, reliable, and transparent scale-out is never an easy nor predictable journey for any operator, particularly with an enormous amount of customer usage rapidly increasing at the same time. Not only must your operations and capacity scale, but so must your development, testing, and deployment processes.
schedule.title: Swift at Scale: The IBM SoftLayer Story

videos.name: Swift at Scale: The IBM SoftLayer Story

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees can expect an overview of the major networking solutions currently available. At the end of the talk they will have all the tools required to make a conscious decision about the networking solution for their projects.
schedule.description: Networking has always been a complicated and delicate topic. It is even more complicated in the world of containers, where huge numbers of containers are continuously created and respawned across entire data centers. There are several container networking choices available, each one with a different implementation and its own peculiarities. The different approaches taken by the different vendors to solve the container networking question can make it daunting to picking the right one for your environment. This talk reviews how the major Linux Container networking solutions work: their implementation details, their strengths and weaknesses, and how they influence the deployment of distributed applications in both container only environments and mixed VM - Container environments.
schedule.problem_addressed: Several Container networking solutions are available, each with its own implementation, design goals and peculiarities. While the differences in the solutions help cover a wide range of usages, they also may lead to a lot of confusion when choosing an appropriate networking solution.  This talk will help to explain and navigate that problem space.
schedule.title: Networking Approaches in a Container World

videos.name: Networking Approaches in a Container World

schedule.description: Traditional carriers have evolved into modern day service providers to include not only voice, video, and data, but also mobility, IoT, cloud and applications. Technologies, like SDN, NFV, and 5G, hold the keys to the networks of the future. Join Red Hat and Ericsson as we discuss the Telecommunication industry’s challenges, successes, and how when applying new technologies and approaches with the open source NFV platform will help transform their organization. During this session you will also hear about the success Ericsson is having with Red Hat technologies.
schedule.title: Red Hat: Evolution of the Modern Day Service Provider Needs

videos.name: Red Hat: Evolution of the Modern Day Service Provider Needs

schedule.description: Deployment factors of geo-distributed Swift using OpenPOWER CPU and hardware covered in this talk.  As an alternative to Intel x86 CPUs, the POWER8 is a 4GHz, 12 core processor with 8 hardware threads per core for a total of 96 threads of parallel execution. It uses 96 MB of eDRAM L3 cache on chip and 128 MB off-chip L4 cache. POWER CPU hardware is as traditional server as well as OCP form factor.  Building on the open edict of OpenStack, the POWER CPU is open source and governed by the OpenPOWER foundation.  With certain applications, it has been shown to be a very power-efficient CPU.  A stable OpenStack component such as Swift makes it a logical candidate for running on a large scale.  Swift has now been ported and is available to run on POWER8-based hardware.
schedule.title: Geo-Distributed Swift Deployments with OpenPOWER Tech Talk

schedule.description: OpenDaylight is the leading open source SDN controller that augments OpenStack’s ability to provision, monitor, manage and secure both physical and virtual routes across the datacenter and/or across the WAN. What makes OpenDaylight so unique and uniquely valuable to OpenStack is it’s ability to interact with network devices via the operator’s protocol of choice. In this talk we’ll explain OpenDaylight’s micro-service style architecture that enables this unprecedented flexibility along with the features of OpenDaylight specifically built in support of OpenStack. We’ll also touch upon what we’ve learned from the growing community of end users who rely on the combination of OpenStack and OpenDaylight to solve their Cloud connectivity needs. Finally, we’ll touch upon some of the current work underway across both OpenStack and OpenDaylight communities much of which is being led from teams within the OPNFV ecosystem.
schedule.title: OpenDaylight: Collaborating with OpenDaylight for a Network-Enabled Cloud

videos.name: OpenDaylight: Collaborating with OpenDaylight for a Network-Enabled Cloud

schedule.description:
NTT Communications has been providing an OpenStack-based public cloud Enterprise Cloud (ECL) since March 01, 2016. Our team is responsible for developing and deploying the customer portal by customizing Horizon of extended interfaces. ECL is now available across 8 regions by July 2016 and expected to expand to 14 regions in near future, which brings urgency of a unified method of deployment and management of components in different regions. We identified several challenges and worked them out as follows.

* How to authenticate existed customer accounts across multiple regions?

   Achieving Single-sign-on by integrating OpenID and Keystone.

* How to release different components in different regions and build the corresponding dashboard menu dynamically and efficiently?

   Applying flexible configuration and deployment method based on YAML

* How to reliably upload large images up to 4TB across all regions via browser?

   Providing the management subsystem for image uploading jobs.
schedule.title: Enterprise Cloud's Unified Customer Portal for Multiple Regions Based on Horizon

schedule.description:
New to OpenStack and want to learn more, but don’t know where or how to get started? This session will show you how to get around the OpenStack website including wiki.openstack.org, docs.openstack.org and etherpad.openstack.org. Not sure what a wiki or an etherpad are? Don’t worry we have you covered.

 

In this session we will also go over more interactive communication tools such as the OpenStack mailing lists and IRC, covering both the technical and social sides.
schedule.title: Communication Tools Lunch and Learn

  • P0 - Marketplace

  • P4 - Restaurantes Dia y Nit

schedule.title: Lunch (click for details)

schedule.description: Since the introduction of z/VM's integrated OpenStack appliance earlier this year, our mainframe support for OpenStack is growing by leaps and bounds.  Learn what we're doing for Newton, how we've helped the LinuxONE community cloud grow and how our CI testing is progressing.   It's a long journey from heavy big iron installations to fluffy, light clouds, but we continue to ascend.
schedule.title: z/VM OpenStack update

schedule.description: In previous presentaion, EasyStack have given demos of providing dedicated cloud in minutes and how to build a Mesos cluster on virtualmachines, In ESCaaS 3.0, we bring kubernetes cluster on multi-tenancy bare metal in elastic dedicated cloud, which based on magnum and Kubernetes, from now on, you can orchestrate container, virtual machine and bare metal on ESCaaS at the same time, which can support your elastic requirement of business and applications
schedule.title: EasyStack: ESCaaS 3.0: Provide Container Orchestration Capability on Multi-Tenancy Baremetal in Dedicated Cloud

videos.name: EasyStack: ESCaaS 3.0: Provide Container Orchestration Capability on Multi-Tenancy Baremetal in Dedicated Cloud

schedule.description: OpenStack’s latest user survey focuses on deployments, revealing changes from the past six months and the community’s evolving attitude toward emerging technologies. Join OpenStack’s User Survey coordinator, Heidi Joy Tretheway, to find out the latest insights from the user survey, ask questions, and take away key talking points.
schedule.title: User Survey Review

schedule.description:
The OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC) operates a 1000-node cluster for the OpenStack community to develop and test features, functionality and code at scale never before possible.  Each day 100s of virtual machines are created and destroyed on the cluster, for numerous workloads including OpenStack infrastructure gate testing.


In this talk, learn about what kind of workloads the community is running on the OSIC clusters that Intel and Rackspace established for the community. We'll look into how OSIC is improving the cluster to handle the load, and how OSIC is using AppFormix to understand resource consumption and optimize the cluster for the OpenStack community.


Come find out what we can all learn from one of the bigger stacks running.
schedule.title: What's up with OSIC, and What Can We Learn From It?

schedule.description:
Releasing working software artifacts is always a challenge. Releasing a huge set of projects like OpenStack increases the difficulty. Luckily, the quality assurance (QA) project has been one of the pillars of OpenStack since its inception. Still, quality is really a shared responsibility in the OpenStack community, and each project should work with the QA team to actively follow, use, and locally adapt the testing tools and guidelines.

In this talk we’ll show how testing is organized in the Sahara world and performed in Sahara’s continuous improvement (CI) system. We’ll discuss the reasons for the creation of the separate Sahara tests repository and the new capabilities it allows. We’ll also share the design of the scenario tests framework itself (end-to-end), and we’ll talk about the consolidation of the Tempest-based and other high-level testing artifacts for related projects.
schedule.title: Scenario Tests, Tempest, CI and Other Beasts in the Sahara World

schedule.description: Attracting internal developers to your private cloud is not a simple matter of assuming that if you build it they will come. A combination of education, tools, and design patterns are needed in order to ensure that your private cloud delivers the highest ROI while avoiding developer skunkworks programs leading to shadow IT. Our panel will discuss practices that have proven successful in fostering a healthy internal development culture.
schedule.title: Intel Corporation: Internal App Dev Programs: A Care and Feeding Guide

videos.name: Intel Corporation: Internal App Dev Programs: A Care and Feeding Guide

schedule.description: Join us in the Foundation Lounge to learn more about the first Project Teams Gathering (PTG), being held in Atlanta this February 2017.
schedule.title: Project Teams Gathering 101

schedule.description: Cisco has open sourced the Vector packet processing (VPP) technology, which provides a high performing production quality virtual switch platform on commodity hardware. I have been contributing code to building a ML2 mechanism driver for the VPP platform. In this presentation, I will provide an overview of the software design, how it works and performs modular L2 port binding leveraging etcd.
schedule.title: A Scalable Neutron ML2 Mechanism Driver for the VPP Platform

schedule.description:
DevOps methodologies accelerate software's development to production pipeline, but how can we make better use of data management technologies to test against production environments and roll back when something goes wrong, minimizing any fallout.

We will show you how Jenkins, Docker and OpenStack can automate this process while protecting your data.
schedule.title: NetApp: DevOps Gets Smart About Data: Make OpenStack, Jenkins & Docker Work Together Without Losing a Thing

videos.name: NetApp: DevOps Gets Smart About Data: Make OpenStack, Jenkins & Docker Work Together Without Losing a Thing

schedule.description:
Half Information is no information. There is a good amount of control plane scale and performance metrics collected by Rally and utilization metrics collected by tools like Monasca/collectl in the context of scale and performance test runs.

Unless these data are correlated there is no meaningful information. In this presentation we propose to aggregate the data from disparate data sources to a centralized analytic platform to perform on demand correlative analysis like 

- what is the memory utilization trend of neutron L3 agent, in a scale of 'n' ports using CVR vs DVR

- What is the I/O utilization on the compute node for VM boot during scale, with windows image vs linux image

- Compare cinder-volume performance against different backends for a scale run of 'n' volumes

- How is the Cloud Controller CPU utilization and nova boot throughtput during a scale run of 'n' VMs against different processor clock speed
schedule.title: On Demand Scale and Performance Data Analytics

schedule.description: Explain how Swisscom collaborated with Ericsson and Ixia to solve their major challenge of monitoring their new NFV based wireless infrastructure. Swisscom network leverages the Ericsson CEE architecture, which runs on OpenStack, and needed a solid solution to monitor the virtual traffic. The three entities collaborated to implement the opensource Tap as a Service added of Ixia CloudLens virtual visibility solutions, bringing traffic filtering capabilities to allow for more efficient usage of resources when monitoring traffic
schedule.title: Tapping in NFV Cloud: A Real World Showcase by Swisscom, Ericsson and IXIA

schedule.description:
In this candid panel discussion with journalists who cover open source cloud technologies, we'll dig into the trends and technologies that will have the greatest impact on OpenStack. We’ll discuss:

  • Emerging technologies including containers, NFV, and the Internet of Things
  • Threats to OpenStack, competing technologies, and both pros and cons about OpenStack
  • The most important trends in cloud technology and how these are likely to affect OpenStack in the future. 

Bring your most provocative questions for this lively debate.
schedule.title: Emerging Technologies, Threats and Opportunities for the Future of Open Source Cloud

videos.name: Emerging Technologies, Threats and Opportunities for the Future of Open Source Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Both technical and non-technical people will benefit from this fun, irreverant and enlightening panel chat. We compare OpenStack and its services to everything from cake to valet parking in an effort to help everyone understand how OpenStack functions. We also challenge each other—and debate where the analogy breaks down—to create a stronger understanding of technology.
schedule.description:
Trying to explain what you do (and why it matters) to friends at the bar, other parents at the PTA, or your relative? Does your new hire or intern truly get it? What about the CFO who has to sign a big check for services... but really needs to wrap her head around what her company is buying first?

We're here to help developers, salespeople and everyone who answers questions about OpenStack to better articulate what we offer, how it works, and how users can benefit. For example: 

  • What's the difference between object storage and block storage?
  • How does networking work in the cloud?
  • Why do for-profit companies benefit from an open source project (and bother contributing back to it)?

Both technical and non-technical people will benefit from this fun, irreverant and enlightening chat. We compare OpenStack and its services to everything from cake to valet parking in an effort to help everyone understand how OpenStack functions.

links.link: There isn't much out there, which is exactly why we felt this was needed.

schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack can be challenging to explain to a non-technical person, but there are strong business cases for being able to explain it in a consise, digestible way. Your organization needs to understand OpenStack and its benefits in order to embrace the technology and the organizational change that goes with it.
schedule.title: From Venti Lattes to Valet Parking: Wacky Analogies to Explain OpenStack

videos.name: From Venti Lattes to Valet Parking: Wacky Analogies to Explain OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendants will be able to learn:

  • How to leverage OpenDaylight capabilities beyond OpenStack Neutron integration
  • Insights into OpenDaylight’s functionality and potential
  • The flexibility and power of API driven development
  • Understand how OpenStack services and concepts can be utilised to manipulate purpose built physical network infrastructure.
  • How OpenStack will drive the future possibilities of SDN
schedule.description:
Neutron provides a rich set of functionality to deliver fully featured networking services between OpenStack tenants. However the roles and responsibilities of Neutron end here, to deliver broader networking capabilities and take programmatic control of the underlying network an SDN controller is of value. OpenDaylight is a popular SDN controller, it provides multiple southbound APIs and a model driven abstraction layer allowing systematic programmability of multi-vendor devices.

Current efforts to integrate OpenDaylight into an OpenStack environment have focused on simply delivering the same functionality as Neutron. In this presentation we will demonstrate how OpenDaylight can be used to configure underlay network elements such as a firewall and expose this ability as a service for OpenStack tenants to take advantage of, essentially allowing physical FWaaS.
schedule.problem_addressed:
NTT West operators required an easy method of providing multi-tenanted XaaS, including IPv6 in a multi-vendor underlay network. To accomplish this NTT West is using an application within OpenDaylight that exposes a model driven REST API that can provision network elements that traditionally only support CLI as a configuration method.
Firewall as a Service (FWaaS) is one example where the SDN Controller is able to manage the firewall vendor specific configuration and at the same time provide an abstraction layer exposed to OpenStack users, admins and services.
This presentation will demonstrate how a FWaaS can be integrated in OpenStack including a Horizon dashboard which allows non-technical (or low-tech) operational staff to handle majority devices configuration tasks without knowledge of the device. The solution provides an automated provisioning workflow for the specific service and operational processes of each type of device.

slides.description:
Neutron provides a rich set of functionality to deliver fully featured networking services between OpenStack tenants. However the roles and responsibilities of Neutron end here, to deliver broader networking capabilities and take programmatic control of the underlying network an SDN controller is of value. OpenDaylight is a popular SDN controller, it provides multiple southbound APIs and a model driven abstraction layer allowing systematic programmability of multi-vendor devices.

Current efforts to integrate OpenDaylight into an OpenStack environment have focused on simply delivering the same functionality as Neutron. In this presentation we will demonstrate how OpenDaylight can be used to configure underlay network elements such as a firewall and expose this ability as a service for OpenStack tenants to take advantage of, essentially allowing physical FWaaS.
slides.name: Presentation Slides

schedule.title: NTT West - Beyond Neutron, Taking Control of a Physical Multi-Vendor Network with OpenDaylight

videos.name: NTT West - Beyond Neutron, Taking Control of a Physical Multi-Vendor Network with OpenDaylight

schedule.description: In the previous OpenStack summit in Austin, we presented how we integrated Ironic into our cloud infrastructure lifecycle management solution. This work represented a first step towards incorporating additional OpenStack components into our solution, including Nova, Neutron, and Keystone. In this talk, we will present how our solution has been redesigned to achieve this goal. This has enabled our solution to participate in the internal convergence of multiple SAP cloud solutions on top of a shared OpenStack layer. This work has presented a number of interesting challenges, from which we have gained useful insights that we wish to share.
schedule.title: Integrating Additional OpenStack Services into Our Baremetal-as-a-Service Solution

videos.name: Integrating Additional OpenStack Services into Our Baremetal-as-a-Service Solution

schedule.description:
Digital Industrialization is the continuous cycle that organizations can use to turn network and IT infrastructure from a cost into a strategic business asset.

By introducing NFV service providers can operate more efficiently and become more agile. Deployments of NFV have started and today they typically comprise established telecom applications such as virtual EPC, IMS and media functions. But this is just the beginning. NFV infrastructure (NFVi) is also a platform for many applications and services for other industries going forward. We are now preparing for what is to come with 5G and IoT.

This presentation will highlight the need for Digital Industrialization and what it takes to be successful in NFV. It will also discuss how Software-defined Infrastructure facilitates the NFV introduction and makes it both more efficient and flexible e.g. through increased utilization and multi-cloud / multi-VIM capabilities.
schedule.title: Ericsson: Digital Industrialization and the Marriage Between NFVi and Software-Defined Infrastructure

videos.name: Ericsson: Digital Industrialization and the Marriage Between NFVi and Software-Defined Infrastructure

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to learn about data protection in OpenStack, and how disaster recovery can become a much simpler feat to accomplish.

Also, an overview of Karbor project and key features in the Newton release.
schedule.description:
Karbor is a new OpenStack Big Tent project, focused on protecting the Data and Metadata that comprises an OpenStack-deployed Application against loss/damage (e.g. backup, replication) by providing a standard framework of APIs and services that allows vendors to provide plugins through a unified interface.
In this talk, we will present Karbor's vision of an ecosystem for data protection providers, using Karbor to orchestrate backup and restore providers.
We will also show how Karbor can be used inside a Disaster Recovery vendor's stack.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Today, data protection providers focus solely on application data (volumes).

However, service operators need a full service continuity solution, which covers not just the app data, but also the app itself, as well as its metadata (e.g. configuration, setup, network, dependencies, etc.)

Smaug provides a framework of services and APIs to simplify dealing with all aspects of the application data protection to the service admin, while enabling vendors of protection products to offer their unique features, without having to do a painful deep integration with the cloud infrastructure.

Disaster recovery is a much sought after capability, which can be very difficult to deploy and maintain.

Smaug helps by decoupling the data protection aspects from the disaster recovery orchestration, enabling simpler and easier to use solutions.

slides.name: Karbor - An Ecosystem for Data Protection Providers

schedule.title: Karbor - An Ecosystem for Data Protection Providers

videos.name: Karbor - An Ecosystem for Data Protection Providers

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should have a basic understanding of Open vSwitch and how tunnels are used to create overlay networks. They will get an overview of relevant established and new tunnel types and the payload that they carry and will learn what changes are needed in Open vSwitch and the Linux kernel to support these.
schedule.description: Advanced OpenStack cloud networking use cases such as L3-VPN overlays or Service Function Chaining and the corresponding interwork with standard network equipment require SDN vSwitches to support an increasing number of tunneling encapsulations such as MPLS over GRE, VXLAN-GPE, Geneve, NSH, and others to carry any type of payload. Traditionally, the Open vSwitch (OVS) is the de-facto standard SDN vSwitch for OpenStack only supported L2 tunnels. Together with the OVS community we are enhancing OVS to support tunnels that can handle arbitrary payload types, including MPLS, IP or NSH.
schedule.problem_addressed: In this talk we will present an overview of problem and our ongoing work in the OVS and Linux networking communities to support the seamless integration of tunnels that carry non-Ethernet traffic and the corresponding impacts on the Open vSwitch kernel and user-space datapaths to handle non-Ethernet packets in the OpenFlow pipeline.
schedule.title: Layer 3 Tunnel Support for Open vSwitch

videos.name: Layer 3 Tunnel Support for Open vSwitch

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can learn to performance test their cloud in both control plane and data plane scenarios by using Browbeat to orchestrate multiple upstream workload providers. The session will also go over setting up Infrastructure such as Graphite/Grafana to monitor and visualize the state of the cloud actively using collectd. Attendees can also expect to gain familiarity with storing, visualizing and analyzing performance data using the ELK/EFK stack
schedule.description:
Browbeat is an Open Source framework focused on scale, performance and tuning of a deployed OpenStack cloud.  It can provide the following benefits to operators, developers and businesses running OpenStack.

  • Create and orchestrate workloads for performance and scale testing.
  • Automate deployment of common collection and data analysis tools.
  • Identify potential configuration problems and highlight some optimal tuning values
  • Make run-to-run, cloud-to-cloud and build-to-build comparisons by sending test result data bundled with metadata about the cloud to Elasticsearch and visualize via Kibana
  • Provide performance data metrics and results based on Rally and other common tools like Grafana
  • Analyze and tune your Cloud for optimal performance.

In this talk you'll hear from core Browbeat developers around how you can leverage it for your OpenStack deployment along with a demonstration showcasing some of the useful features.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Having access to an efficient, consolidated tool for scalability and performance testing of OpenStack has been a long-needed gap when deploying a production OpenStack cloud.  Browbeat strives to bridge these gaps while tieing in standard tools and visualization/metrics for easy presentation of performance and scale data.

We utilize and bundle installation of common Open Source tools like Graphite/Grafana/Collectd and the Elasticsearch, Logstash/Fluentd, and Kibana (ELK/EFK) stack to provide cohesive, intuitive graphing, metrics and visualization.

slides.name: OpenStack Scale and Performance Testing with Browbeat

schedule.title: OpenStack Scale and Performance Testing with Browbeat

videos.name: OpenStack Scale and Performance Testing with Browbeat

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees should expect to learn:

  • How to report a security bug,
  • How the VMT triages security reports,
  • The definition of an embargoed disclosure, and
  • What happens when a security fix is released.
schedule.description:
In this session we’ll introduce the OpenStack Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) process to those who aren't familiar with OpenStack bug report.

We’ll demonstrate the OpenStack vulnerability management team's typical workflow for handling security vulnerability reports, and we’ll share practical tips and tricks based on previous CVE bugs. You’ll learn how to successfully report a security bug in OpenStack, how we triage security reports, and what happens when a security fix is released.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session addresses faqs that arrise when a security bug is found. Security bug needs special care due to potential production damages.
schedule.title: I Found a Security Bug: What Happens Next?

videos.name: I Found a Security Bug: What Happens Next?

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session dives into best practices on how to properly backup and restore an OpenStack environment from a failed update and will provide attendees the answers to the critical questions:

  • What do I need to back up for the overcloud nodes and undercloud node?
  • What is the restore process for the overcloud nodes and undercloud node?
schedule.description:
With each OpenStack version release, new components, services, and feature sets are included to improve overall functionality. However, with the advantage of those new features comes the very real possibility of having an OpenStack failed update. Prior to attempting an update,  you are likely to ask yourself:

  • What do I need to back up prior to the update?
  • How do I backup my databases?
  • How do I restore my databases?
  • If I need to rollback all of the services, which do I start first?

To answer these questions you need a comprehensive strategy to backup and restore from a failure.  This session dives into best practices on how to properly backup and restore an OpenStack environment from a failed update and will provide attendees the answers to the critical questions:

  • What do I need to back up for the overcloud nodes and undercloud node?
  • What is the restore process for the overcloud nodes and undercloud node?
schedule.problem_addressed:
Prior to attempting an OpenStack update,  you are likely to ask yourself:

  • What do I need to back up prior to the update?
  • How do I backup my databases?
  • How do I restore my databases?
  • If I need to rollback all of the services, which do I start first?
schedule.title: Failed OpenStack Update?! Now What?

videos.name: Failed OpenStack Update?! Now What?

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees should expect to learn:

  1. Considerations for working with WFH colleagues when you work in an office
  2. How to maintain a good team culture when you are working in a remote team
  3. Tips on how to work from home efficiently and effectively
  4. How to maintain effective online communication between team members
schedule.description:
In the UK, the number of people WFH has increased by a fifth in the last ten years. In the US, the number of people WFH has increased 103% since 2005.

Technology enables us to communicate more-or-less solely online, eradicating the need for human interaction, and allowing us to WFH on the project we love. However, with all the benefits of WFH, it can also be isolating, lonely, difficult, and a struggle.

As a documenter for OpenStack, the most important thing I do every day is communicate online with people I do not know to ensure my job is conducted effectively and efficiently. Communication online is key to creating, forming, and maintaining a successful project. This presentation will cover:

  1. Consideration for working with WFH colleagues when you work in an office
  2. How maintain effective online communication between team members
  3. How to use online communication to create a good team culture with your remote team
  4. Tips on how to work from efficiently and effectively
schedule.problem_addressed: This presentation aims to improve the communication within a team, from the perspective of a remote work, and an office worker with remote colleagues, and helps to understand the challenges faced in both scenarios.
schedule.title: Home and Away: A Work from Home Episode

videos.name: Home and Away: A Work from Home Episode

schedule.description: The Kubernetes OpenStack Special Interest Group (SIG) is a rallying point for folks who are contributing to Kubernetes with the aim of offering improved integration with OpenStack, the open source cloud computing platform. Come join members of the SIG for this working group as we review current state of integration and paln next steps in this exciting area.
schedule.title: Kubernetes OpenStack Special Interest Group (SIG)

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Technical tools, tips, and processes to put in place to achieve operational efficiciency on OpenStack, and be able to drive in place updates and upgrades.
schedule.description:
According to OpenStack users survey, Cloud Foundry is the 2nd most popular workload on OpenStack. You want to deploy Cloud Foundry on OpenStack or already have. What's next?

Cloud Foundry continues to evolve with revolutionary changes, e.g move from bosh-micro to bosh-init, using the new eCPI, move to Diego etc.

Same with OpenStack, e.g changes from Keystone v2 to v3, from Liberty to Mitaka, network plugins changes etc. Both IaaS and PaaS layers are changing frequently. How do you do in-place updates/upgrades/operational tasks without impacting user experience at both the layers?

In this talk will discuss our lessons learnt operating hybrid Cloud Foundry deployments on top of OpenStack over the last two years and how we used underlying technologies to seamlessly operate them

1. BOSH
2. Razor
3. Ansible playbooks via Ursula
4. Jenkins 
5. Graphite-ELK
6. Rally

We will also detail community tools to validate if Cloud Foundry deployment will work on your OpenStack etc.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to do seamless and in place updates/upgrades/operational tasks on OpenStack, so that workloads above dont get affected. In addition, how to handle the confliciting requirements when the workload above, in this case Cloud Foundry, itself is changing constantly and going through updates and upgrades of it own.

slides.name: Operations as a Service: Lessons Learnt Operating Multiple Cloud Foundry on OpenStack Deployments

schedule.title: Operations as a Service: Lessons Learnt Operating Multiple Cloud Foundry on OpenStack Deployments

videos.name: Operations as a Service: Lessons Learnt Operating Multiple Cloud Foundry on OpenStack Deployments

schedule.description: Telcos are increasingly looking to take advantage of mobile edge computing to support their IoT initiatives. Whether this is for smart metering, security, video delivery or mobile usage analytics, these are new services that can create new revenue opportunities beyond providing simple bandwidth. Developing software for such systems is very different from today's cloud computing methodologies. This talk will present the issues involved and how development processes must change in order to make these types of deployments successful.
schedule.title: Red Hat: Mobile Edge Computing in Support of IoT

videos.name: Red Hat: Mobile Edge Computing in Support of IoT

schedule.description: At the DefCore Working Group Work Session we will be preparing the 2017.01 guideline and other issues related to the interop efforts of the WG.
schedule.title: Interop (DefCore) Working Group Work Session

schedule.description: TBD
schedule.title: FNTECH Production

schedule.description:
RSVP REQUIRED: https://susetraining.eventbrite.com


This training is a two day course spread across three days - 1/2 day on Tuesday, 1/2 day on Wednesday, full day on Thursday. Participants must attend all days in order to complete the course. (The course is spread across three days to allow attends the opportunity to attend other sessions at the conference in addition to this training). 

Attendees must have a Full Access pass to the OpenStack Summit Barcelona in order to attend this training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This course is designed for system administrators and others who want to learn how to administer an OpenStack Cloud. Participants receive a comprehensive understanding of the tasks necessary to administer an OpenStack cloud and then use common tools that are included with an OpenStack distribution to administer a SUSE OpenStack cloud. This course prepares the participants to take and pass the Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) exam.
schedule.title: RSVP Required: SUSE Three-Day Training: OpenStack Administration - Prepare for the Certified Exams

schedule.description:
Milton Friedman wrote a book title "There's No Such Thing as a Free Lunch" and we are here to tell you that he is wrong, there is and its called Nuage Networks eXperience (Nuage X). But first, we will give you some background, share with you some of the challenges we faced and conclude with how we utilized OpenStack, Nuage Networks VSP and some code to launch a free, on-demand cloud service that gives developers access to opensource code and free resources to test and build something amazing with Nuage Networks VSP.

Oh, and we will also show you a demo and if you are lucky, we will have time to tell you how to sign-up
schedule.title: Nuage Networks: Nuage X | One Small Step for SDN, One Giant Leap for the DevOps Community

videos.name: Nuage Networks: Nuage X | One Small Step for SDN, One Giant Leap for the DevOps Community

schedule.description:
In this Brown Bag talk named "Data Cloning as a Service", we will demonstrate how to automate the cloning of a 24 x 7 Mission critical database from a Production tenant to a testing tenant.

Ansible is used to place an enterprise database (oracle in this case) in backup mode, take a snapshot of the volume containing the Database, clone the cinder volume and get it transferred to a development tenant who will automatically start a clone of the database for testing and QA.

The audience will walk out of this session with an understanding of how OpenStack can be leveraged on creative ways to automate complex tasks that would otherwise take countless hours to perform in a traditional IT environment.
schedule.title: Data Cloning as a Service in a Programable Infrastructure

schedule.description:
In recent years, our OpenStack private cloud resources (65k+ VM, 25k vCPU, 350TB memory) that support Yahoo! JAPAN web services require 6x network performance per server compared with traditional server farm as a result of VM aggregation and higher density. Additionally, huge and/or burst network traffic (5~10x than ordinary) we have often received from internet. More internal backend traffic (DNS, RDB, MQ, etc.) happend accordingly. In such situations, we faced a network performance issue in our cloud.

To overcome this, we have adopted Open vSwitch with DPDK as a software L2 switch on HyperVisor instead of LinuxBridge, built new mitaka cluster (serving 8000+ VM scale) on OCP (Open Compute Project) servers, and started operation phase now.
As we found many problems through our activities from OvS/DPDK PoC phase to operation phase, we will present about combination limitation related OvS/DPDK/NIC driver, network architecture/performance, L7 SLA, operation perspective, and future works.
schedule.title: How Did Our Private Cloud Realize Better Application SLA Using Open vSwitch with DPDK

schedule.description:
How can we achieve human-centric innovation and leverage the Internet of Things through use of AI?

In this Marketplace demo – led by Fujitsu Hybrid IT CTO, Jason Daniels and featuring Principal Researcher, Roger Menday from Fujitsu Laboratories Europe - we will introduce recent machine learning innovations from the Laboratories, highlighting real life application scenarios in Handwriting, Driving and 3D object recognition.

We will also take a look at creating a Cloud environment which supports our Artificial Intelligence. For example, how to deploy machine learning libraries (such as Caffe) and following an API-first approach. Using OpenStack and Cloud Foundry, we will present our journey from experiments in the Labs to the Fujitsu Cloud Service K5 public cloud.
schedule.title: Fujitsu: Artificial Intelligence powered by OpenStack and Cloud Foundry

videos.name: Fujitsu: Artificial Intelligence powered by OpenStack and Cloud Foundry

schedule.description:
-    Sphinx is a tool that makes it easy to create intelligent and structured documentation.
-    With increasing projects in openstack managing documents could be a tedious task, why not to write code which generates documents for you.
-         We will be covering various aspects like using extensions, generating different output formats and many more interesting things to do with it.
schedule.title: Got Bored of Doing Code Documentation? Try Sphinx

schedule.description: Imagine being able to stand up thousands of tenants with thousands of apps, running thousands of Docker-formatted container images and routes, all on a self-healing cluster. Now, take that one step further with all of those images being updatable through a single upload to the registry, and with zero downtime. In this session, Steve Gordon of the Red Hat OpenStack Platform team will show you just that. Steve will walk through a recent benchmarking deployment using the Cloud Native Computing Foundation’s (CNCF) new 1,000 node cluster with OpenStack and Red Hat’s OpenShift Container Platform, the enterprise-ready Kubernetes for developers.
schedule.title: Red Hat: Deploying Containers at Scale on OpenStack

videos.name: Red Hat: Deploying Containers at Scale on OpenStack

schedule.description: Enterprises and Telcos around the world are choosing OpenStack to transform their business. Join Mark Interrante, Senior Vice President, R&D, for HPE as he shares insights on customer trends in OpenStack and the Enterprise, how OpenStack is leading in key workloads and where we go from here.
schedule.title: HPE: OpenStack and the Enterprise

videos.name: HPE: OpenStack and the Enterprise

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Walmart wants to show users what has and has not worked for us on our journey to change our culture to embrace innovation and out of the box thinking.
schedule.description: Walmart started its OpenStack journey with our eCommerce site.  Open source is a priority in our approach to new development and embracing new solutions.  We want to share our journey as we continue to build a successful open source culture, making it a focused and integral part of our day to day planning, operation and execution.  We will explore our successes and failures as we continue to grow our community involvement and participation.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to implement a successful open source culture in your organization.
schedule.title: How Walmart is Building a Successful Open Source Culture

videos.name: How Walmart is Building a Successful Open Source Culture

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about the ETSI MANO specification and all the available options for addressing NFV Orchestration including how OpenStack is evolving to meet the needs. Hopefully, attendees will learn how the panel plans to harmonize these efforts. This panel will invite all the key leaders of these Orchestrator projects to jointly discuss how could this cooperation could really happen, also some key issues will be identified such as what scope level of ETSI information model will be useful for the implementation, and would OPNFV be good candidate to embrace multiple orchestrator projects, how TOSCA and YANG model will be used to represent different modules, how to work with legacy OSS system, etc.
schedule.description:
There are many open source orchestrator projects which are attempting to accelerate SDN/NFV deployment in operator networks, Open Source MANO is targeting how to deploy NFV based on the ETSI MANO specification; OpenStack Tacker starts from a VNF manager and is evolving from there with the help of other projects; Open-O (Orchestrator) explores areas beyond the MANO specification by including SDN orchestrator, legacy networks, and OSS; ManageIQ and others could evolve from cloud/IT managers into an NFV orchestrator; and at the same time, AT&T published the ECOMP whitepaper which augments the ETSI MANO story with policy, closed loop control, VNF onboarding, SDN configuration.

This panel will address how we plan to harmonize multiple orchestrator projects to better align on modular code within each project. There are many common new modules like Parser, VNF onboarding, EPA, Generic VNF managers, event streaming, which could benefit from the cooperation among multiple open source projects.
schedule.problem_addressed: Multiple available choices are available to an operator when choosing which tool they use to fulfill the ETSI MANO specification and beyond the MANO specification. The available choices include the evolution of existing OSS/BSS systems, many scenarios of OpenStack and OpenDaylight, Open Source MANO, Open-O, and ECOMP.
schedule.title: OpenStack and the Orchestration Options for Telecom / NFV

videos.name: OpenStack and the Orchestration Options for Telecom / NFV

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees are able to learn about current activity at Ironic, Cinder, Nova and Magnum at upstream.
schedule.description:
Storage is an essential part of any computing systems.

In OpenStack, Cinder provides persistent storage, but currently, Ironic only supports integrated storage and is not available Cinder volume as an external storage.

By utilizing external storage at Ironic, user can run enterprise workloads on bare metal servers to ensure stable and predictable performance, and better data consistency etc. Also this can be applied to containerized apps on top of baremetal node. Enterprise workloads such as Database, fail over with state-full application on container need persistent and stable storage.

There are two ongoing effort and one lacking feature to enable volume support for containerized apps on baremetal.

- [Ironic] Cinder volume support
- [Magnum] Ironic support
- [Magnum] Volume support on baremetal node(not started)

In this session, we explain recent updates of Ironic and Cinder integration effort and then discuss Ironic support for Magnum and volume support for container.
schedule.problem_addressed: Storage is essential requirement not only for virtual computing systems but also physical computing systems and also containerezed applications. This session introduces current activity to support storage of Ironic, Ironic for Magnum support and future task of volume support for container.
schedule.title: Give Me Cinder Volume for Containerized Apps on Top of Baremetal Node!

videos.name: Give Me Cinder Volume for Containerized Apps on Top of Baremetal Node!

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this session the attendees will get an update about the most important new features introduced during last year as well as the new components in the Monasca family. We will also describe how Monasca integrates with other projects to get the best reliability for your OpenStack deployment.
schedule.description:
Monasca was accepted into the OpenStack Big Tent about a year ago and has come a long way and is under rapid development. It is the OpenStack Monitoring as a Service (MONaaS) project with a focus on metrics and log management. This session will provide an update and overview on the current state of the project including the following.

Exciting new features that have been added:

  • Deterministic alarms
  • Non-periodic notifications
  • Alarms on logs, correlation of metrics and logs
  • OVS vSwitch monitoring

Major new areas of development such as:

  • Monasca Log API
  • Monasca Transform and Aggregation Engine
  • Monasca Analytics.

Updates on the project including:

  • Integrations with other OpenStack projects including Heat, Ceilometer and Congress.
  • Integrations with third-party projects such as Grafana, ELK and others.
  • Community involvement and ecosystem.
  • Active deployments and companies/organizations that are using Monasca in their distributions and products.
  • What's next for Monasca?
schedule.problem_addressed: Monitoring large scale production OpenStack environments presents new challenges for public, managed, and private cloud providers. An effective cloud monitoring  strategy will lower your mean time to resolution, decrease TCO, and increase the stability of the OpenStack platform.
schedule.title: Monasca: One Year Later

videos.name: Monasca: One Year Later

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: What new additions we made into oslo in the last cycle, how those additions (or changes) can be used by developers and operators and how new contributors (or old) can add new patterns and changes into the various oslo libraries (to further increase the commonality across the openstack projects).
schedule.description:
A large number of changes happened in oslo libraries over the last cycle. We would like the opportunity to be able to showcase, explain, and educate contributors to what these changes are.

  • oslo.policy  - implemented embed policy defaults in code and allow for a policy file to override them.  This would allow deployers to only configure policies that they specifically want to override.
  • oslo.messaging(zmq) - There were zmq driver deployment configurations added like proxy and pub-sub . we'll talk about these variants of deployment and what benefits you can get using zmq driver.
  • oslo.config - Mutable config is the ability to reload configuration (also logging configuration!) at runtime without a service restart. It is live in Nova Newton now.
  •  oslo.messaging AMQP 1.0 driver - Introduce the new router-based messaging backend supported by the Newton release. Targetted to deployers who'd like to "kick the tires" of this backend.
schedule.problem_addressed: Education and dissemenation around what the oslo group and the supporting libraries it maintains have provided over the last cycle and how they can be used.

slides.name: Live from Oslo

schedule.title: Live from Oslo

videos.name: Live from Oslo

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session attendees will learn the following:

  • Introduction to OpenStack Heat and Ansible
  • Different use cases for deploying applications within OpenStack
  • Challenges surrounding complex software deployments
  • How OpenStack Heat and Ansible provide solutions
  • Next steps including step-by-step guide

Attendees will leave with not only with new understanding around automation as it pertains to OpenStack but a guide to get going, including Heat templates.
schedule.description: Automation is the only way operations teams will keep pace with growing business expectations to deliver faster, increase availability and do so efficiently without adding more resources. OpenStack offers the infrastructure blueprints, API endpoints and Heat for delivering one-click infrastructure-as-a-service. Ansible provides an agentless platform for configuring, deploying and automating complex application software stacks in the cloud once the infrastructure is provisioned. Together OpenStack Heat and Ansible provide end-to-end solutions for deploying even the most complex application stacks, effortlessly.
schedule.problem_addressed: Heat was originally designed to be image based, the idea was to change images and simply redeploy. While Heat is great for these cases, complex software deployments and configurations require additional capabilities. Ansible was designed to be a next-gen software deployment and configuration management tool for the cloud. Together Ansible and Heat solve even the most complex software deployment challenge and provide end-to-end cloud automation.
schedule.title: OpenStack and Ansible: Automation Born in the Cloud

videos.name: OpenStack and Ansible: Automation Born in the Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Topics covered will include: selection of hardware for optimal costs, techniques that drive quality and service levels up, common deployment mistakes, in place upgrades, how to identify the maturity level of each project and decide what is ready for production, and much more. For the grand finale you will learn how the cost of your OpenStack cloud compares to Amazon AWS and whether you will save money by rolling your own.
schedule.description: Real world lessons and war stories about Catalyst IT’s experience in rolling out an OpenStack based public cloud in New Zealand. This is an opportunity to learn first-hand about useful techniques we have used to increase service levels, perform in place upgrades and how the cost of your own OpenStack cloud compares to Amazon AWS.
schedule.problem_addressed: This presentation will provide tips and advice that may save you a lot of time, money and nights of sleep if you are planning to run OpenStack in the future. It may also bring some insights to people that are already running OpenStack in production.
schedule.title: Things You MUST Know Before You Deploy OpenStack

videos.name: Things You MUST Know Before You Deploy OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will cover the technical detail of:

  • Evaluating OpenStack, Building and automating a CI environment for a mix of bare metal and cloud servers. 
  • What are the network limitations of OpenStack and how we creatively leverage VLANs to handle large packet per seconds. 
  • How to efficiently monitor your cloud infrastructure 
  • Find quickly your bottlenecks 
  • What we missed and should be consider before moving in house 
  • Lesson Learned and Post Cost Analysis
schedule.description: It can be easy to come up with a TCO analysis that would challenge any public cloud and make you think, "let's go in-house!". What are the challenges and is it really worth it? The TubeMogul Operation team went thru the technical challenges at building a private cloud. In this presentation you will learn how the team went from a R&D to an automated deployment of a bare-metal servers to finally migrate a large workload from a Public Cloud to its own Private Cloud infrastructure. We will detail how the team dealt with unexpected issues and also how we chose the hardware, estimated capacity, stay cost effective, improve overall performance of the system, and bring better control and visibility.
schedule.problem_addressed: He are showing how a small start-up over-commed the complex skills ramp-up of openstack to meet financial goals. This is of interest for anyone thinking to move out of the Public Cloud and build their own Private Cloud solution.
schedule.title: Moving Large Workloads from a Public Cloud to an OpenStack Private Cloud: Is It Really Worth It?

videos.name: Moving Large Workloads from a Public Cloud to an OpenStack Private Cloud: Is It Really Worth It?

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• how to develop a requirement suitable for open source development
  • how to find out the right people who can help
  • appropriate communication techniques with open source community
  • best way to write blueprints
schedule.description: Presentation on what it takes tosuccessfully contribute upstream to OpenStack. PTLs and committers from telecom operators, vendors, and OpenStack core developers in the OPNFV Doctor project will discuss key lessons and takeaways from their successful and ongoing contributions to OpenStack. Attendees will also hear from OpenStack PTLs working directly with OPNFV Doctor to incorporate components into OpenStack. Hear details on what works, what doesn't and gain valuable insights on how best to integrate upstream.
schedule.problem_addressed:
New participants with little or no open source experience often find it quite difficult to join open source, let alone make successful contributions. OPNFV brought many telecom operators on board and provided a place to refine their requirements to upstream (e.g. OpenStack). "Doctor", which is a requirement on fault management for telecom infrastructure, was initiated by a mobile telecom operator. Although the Doctor project started as a requirement analysis project, is has already implemented most of its required features in OpenStack.

However, reaching upstream was not an easy task. The success of Doctor represents a fruitful collaboration among telecom operators with their precise technical requirements with an end-to-end view, OPNFV open source experts with telecom experience, and the OpenStack developers. This presentation explains, from practical working experience, some useful methods and work styles that can facilitate involvement and success across open source communities.

slides.name: How to Work Upstream with OpenStack

schedule.title: How to Work Upstream with OpenStack

videos.name: How to Work Upstream with OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
For operators deploying OpenStack:

  • Navigating around the 50+ projects in the big tent.
  • How to decide which projects are right for your use case in your deployment.

For everyone:

  • How to deal with authentication without keystone federation being a thing using OpenStack client config.
  • Having a more consistent and predictable interface with the OpenStack client effort.

For application developers:

  • Dealing with inconsistencies in interfaces with python software development kits like Shade.

For operators using public and private clouds:

  • Orchestrating resources consistently between private and public clouds using tools like Ansible which benefit from OpenStack client config, and shade!
schedule.description:
Why the heck do I need to know Cinder gives me volumes, or that Nova has something to do with compute? What is a Cloud Kitty?

Fact, OpenStack public clouds today expose different versions to users. Just wait until you see the face on the application developer when she learns her application only works on some OpenStack clouds.

In addition deployers of OpenStack clouds have to be aware of a big tent. What does that even mean? Which of the 50+ OpenStack projects do I need in order to be considered an OpenStack cloud?

Join Mike Perez who is employed by the OpenStack Foundation, focusing on cross-project initiatives in the OpenStack project as he navigates through the open source tools available today for consumers, deployers and developers building and interacting with OpenStack public/private/hybrid clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed:
App Developers:

The Shade SDK has identified five different ways public clouds expose external IPs to users today. This is a horrible experience for any app dev learning their app only works with one OpenStack cloud.

Deployers:

Confusion with OpenStack's big tent of 50+ projects. The goal here is to help deployers focus on the number one thing: their use case. Following the minimum set by DefCore to obtain using the OpenStack trademark, we'll look at how to properly evaluate projects in the big tent and to navigate to picking only the ones needed.

End users:

Why do I need to know a Cinder gives me a volume? Lets instead focus on what really matters as an end user. I want some resources based on a set of requirements. We will look at how the OpenStack community is developing OpenStack client which focuses on this very idea to help user experience. In addition having the ability to better way to authenticate from cloud to cloud in a world where federated clouds never came to be.

slides.name: Keep Calm, And Use OpenStack Consistently

schedule.title: Keep Calm, And Use OpenStack Consistently

videos.name: Keep Calm, And Use OpenStack Consistently
