schedule.title: OpenStackID - Get on board!

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session is going to explain best practices, pros and cons of using unikernel from the perspective of the HPC. It will explain the unikernel concept and approach, explain the architecture chosen in this case study and present its major limitations. It will use a real world application based on OpenFOAM CFD simulation to introduce the steps necessary to ensure full compatibility with Linux-based guests.

We are also going to delve into the highly flexible management layer of the OSv itself, as well as the newly developed application packaging mechanisms enhancing flexibility of running arbitrary workloads independent of the actual environment: local, private/public cloud or HPC. Pilot integration with OpenStack dashboard will be used as a real-world showcase.

The session will conclude by outlining several other benefits that the MIKELANGELO project focuses on and are tightly coupled with our choice of the unikernel-based HPC: improved paravirtual I/O and virtual RDMA.
schedule.description:
This session explains lessons learned integrating HPC workloads with unikernels on top of OpenStack.

HPC workloads are traditionally executed in general purpose operating systems running directly on the host. Virtualized and containerised environments using these base systems are being adopted to improve flexibility and manageability of the infrastructure. To this end, the MIKELANGELO project is using a lightweight unikernel (OSv) providing bare minimum, but fully virtualized environment to these workloads. We are going to present a flexible application management that has been implemented specifically to support integration with cloud middlewares, such as OpenStack. This allows dynamic composition and execution of workloads based on user's needs. OpenFOAM CFD is being used to showcase our approach, including an integration into OpenStack dashboard. Finally, we will show how the use of a flexible telemetry system delivers in-depth insights into the infrastructure and application.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Users of traditional HPC clusters are presented with a set of strict limitations in terms of the operating system and available software packages. Development and testing of HPC applications also typically involves specific configuration and compilation of the source code which cannot be easily tested in a development environment. Virtualization and the cloud itself offer significant benefits as well as drawbacks, such as performance loss and overall overheads of typical operating systems.

This session tackles an alternative approach to running HPC applications in the cloud exploiting the OSv unikernel. OSv has been designed from the ground up specifically for the cloud. However it suffers from several limitations in terms of HPC, which are discussed in this session: heavily parallelised workloads, Linux compatibility, HPC-specific infrastructure (e.g. RDMA NICs and NFS) and application management. We will show how these have been overcome using a widely popular OpenFOAM application.
schedule.title: HPC, Unikernels and OpenStack

videos.name: HPC, Unikernels and OpenStack

schedule.description:
How can we in the OpenStack community work together better? How can the TC be better stewards of the OpenStack communtiy? How do we all agree on what OpenStack is? So lots of big scary questions here, but the SWG is taking time out to develop recomendations on how we improve the way we work. We already have a session about the OpenStack wide goals process, in this session lets discuss the SWG by looking at the effort to document how we work together today.

References:
* https://governance.openstack.org/resolutions/20160705-stewardship.html
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/357260/

Session Leader(s): gothicmindfood, ttx
schedule.title: Cross Project Workshops: "Re-Inventing the TC", the Stewardship Working Group Discussion

schedule.description:
Nova, Neutron, Cinder, and Ironic are pursuing rolling, minimal-downtime upgrades using oslo.versionedobjects. Keystone and Glance are pursuing rolling, zero-downtime upgrades using database triggers. Swift has had rolling, zero-downtime upgrades forever. Horizon needs to be able to talk to multiple releases of every service it interacts with. Regardless of the implementations, testing real upgrades while measuring and/or asserting against downtime in the gate might be the hardest part. Let's review the state of the union, where we're headed, and what's it going to take from your project for us to deliver the latest version of OpenStack to deployers and end users without all the risk, frustration, and downtime of the past.

References:
* User story
* Upgrades
* Rolling upgrades
* Zero-downtime upgrades

Session Leader(s): Dolph Mathews (dolphm)
schedule.title: Cross Project Workshops: Rolling Upgrades, and the Road to Zero-Downtime

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should walk out from the session aware of presence of various Cinder features that increase its control and data plane availability and with knowledge how to use them correctly for different tasks.
schedule.description:
Cinder (OpenStack Block Storage project) can be found in >80% of OpenStack deployments. Configuring it to be robust, resilient and fast is important. However considering its high customizability, such as choice of deployment architecture, volume backend or backup backend, an always on Cinder is not a simple goal to achieve.

In this talk we will explain how Cinder can be deployed in ways guaranteeing increased reliability and performance, as close as possible to "always on". We will walk you through latest innovations that are letting you keep your control plane and data plane up during upgrades, increased load or when experiencing breakdowns. These features include:

  • cinder-volume service in A/A mode
  • rolling upgrades support
  • volume replication
  • volume migration

We will also share insight on the improvements in these matters that are planned for the future cycles.
schedule.problem_addressed: We want to address general problem of availability, reliability and scalability of OpenStack Cinder control and data plane.

slides.name: Cinder Always On - Reliability And Scalability Guide

schedule.title: Cinder Always On - Reliability And Scalability Guide

videos.name: Cinder Always On - Reliability And Scalability Guide

schedule.description:
Considering the increasing amount of applications running in containers, providing a reliable and efficiently operable container infrastructure is crucial, particularly at global scale. Running Kubernetes (an open source system for automatic deployment, scaling and management of containerized applications), on-top of OpenStack has proven to be popular for container management. However, one of the main challenges to date of implementing this is the missing operational link between OpenStack and Kubernetes.

 

In this session, we will show how Kubernetes running on OpenStack can be comfortably and effectively monitored with Monasca; the scalable, multi-tenant, high performance, fault-tolerant OpenStack ‘Monitoring as a Service’ (MONaaS) solution. We will also explore the integration steps undertaken to forward metrics and logs to the centralized OpenStack monitoring service – and explain how the collected information can be utilized in Monasca for operations like alerting and log management.

 

In the live demo we will send the notification to the Hipchat room. To join the room, please follow the linkhttps://www.hipchat.com/gEcgyVtXC
schedule.title: Fujitsu: Monasca Monitoring for Kubernetes – Delivered on OpenStack

videos.name: Fujitsu: Monasca Monitoring for Kubernetes – Delivered on OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Basic understanding of various consumption models.
schedule.description:
Panelist : Amar Kapadia (Mirantis), James Page (Canonical), and VS Joshi from EMC.

Moderator: Ashish Nadkarni (IDC)

In this panel, experts will discuss the pros and cons of various OpenStack consumption models. We will take a critical view of the various options that are available for building an OpenStack cloud. Is DIY the best path or are there trade-offs? Should you be concerned with vendor lock-in leveraging a distribution or turnkey model? What considerations should you take into account when deciding between these options of DIY or Distro or Turnkey? Join these experts as they discuss the good, the bad, and the ugly with each path to a building a successful OpenStack powered organization.
schedule.problem_addressed: Many attendees (about 50%) at the summit are beginners. The first thing thing that they need to understand are the basics of OpenStack..How it can be consumed? What are the various consumption models etc. This panel will throw light on the various consumption models..
schedule.title: The Good, Bad and Ugly: OpenStack Consumption Models

videos.name: The Good, Bad and Ugly: OpenStack Consumption Models

schedule.description:
Building a cloud strategy for your company is not a simple task. If you are evaluating your cloud strategy and considering OpenStack, this session is for you. IBM is all about open technologies and building open cloud solutions that enable clients to quickly deploy their workloads on cloud infrastructure.
 
In this session, Jesse Proudman, IBM Blue Box CTO and Distinguished Engineer, and Azmir Mohamed, IBM Blue Box Product Manager, will share IBM's cloud strategy and point of view on market direction. 
 
You will learn about different use cases for local, dedicated, and public cloud deployment models and how they address different client expectations. With so many companies supporting OpenStack, you need to do your homework. Hear details about what differentiates IBM Cloud as a provider.
schedule.title: IBM: The Open Cloud: A Platform of Possibilities

videos.name: IBM: The Open Cloud: A Platform of Possibilities

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Configuration and Tools used for:
- Source control
- Bug tracking
- Continuous integration
schedule.description: As a company that develops software on OpenStack, wouldn’t it be amazing if you could use the same robust continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) process that enables thousands of distributed developers to create reliable software at a blazing pace?  What if setting up this kind of system had an “Easy” button?  Well, the OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC) QA/CI team is here to help. We’ll walk through a series of best practices and lessons learned from setting up a CI/CD system using open-sourced tools. Your team will be able to leverage the same proven development process used by OpenStack developers upstream.  After this talk you’ll be able to increase your development team’s time-to-market,  efficiency and reliability, and you don't have to be a sysadmin or an IT manager to do it!
schedule.problem_addressed:
You are a developer who has been given the task of developing an application on OpenStack?  You now have to find out how you will handle your application management and development process.  Our aim is to assist developers in this position with that very question.  We will provide a proven set of tools used for application management and continuous integration based off our own experience developing applications on OpenStack.  These tools will allow the developer to leverage the battle tested software process used upstream.
 
Benefits:
- Defines an application management style
- Decreases time searching for tools implementing this style
- Allows developers to focus on code!
- Allows managers to have more transparency
schedule.title: OpenStack CI/CD for Everyone Else

videos.name: OpenStack CI/CD for Everyone Else

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will walk away with best practices and configurations they can make to improve the reliabilty and perfomance of messaging in OpenStack.
schedule.description:
Operating RabbitMQ at large scale comes with it's own set of challenges. This talk will take you on the journey Cisco faced with operating a large (800+ node) environment inside a single RabbitMQ cluster. We will share the pains, lessons learned and best practices to stabilize and improve messaging performance and reliability.

This talk includes:

  • OpenStack service configurations related to messaging
  • Kombu driver enhancements
  • Considerations when virtualizing the control plane, and how default network buffer settings can be insufficient.
  • RabbitMQ Erlang arguments related to TCP_USER_TIMEOUT and their impact
  • The overhead of Queue Mirroring
  • Kernel level network settings to improve RabbitMQ failover and provide faster service re-connect
  • Alerting and Monitoring RabbitMQ
  • Recovering from a cluster partition
  • Architectural decisions
schedule.problem_addressed: Large deployments of RabbitMQ struggle with default kernel and system settings. Errors like MessageTimedOut and cluster partioning will be addressed.

slides.name: RabbitMQ at Scale, Lessons Learned

schedule.title: RabbitMQ at Scale, Lessons Learned

videos.name: RabbitMQ at Scale, Lessons Learned

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We will detail the use-cases for these BGP VPN interconnections, the basics of the API introduced, and outline how the BGPVPN service plugin and its drivers allow the implementation to be based on SDN controllers --three as of today-- or on the Neutron-based driver.

After telling you the story of the project and what you can do with it, we will explain how we worked in the Neutron stadium and the synergies found between Openstack and OPNFV, and tell you what is coming next.
schedule.description:
The networking-bgpvpn Neutron stadium project allows to create connectivity between Neutron Ports, via their Networks and Routers, to BGP/MPLS VPNs.

These VPNs are a cornerstone of telecom operators' backbones and interconnect datacenters, businesses or NFV POPs. Interconnecting them on-demand with Openstack is a critical piece of the NFV and hybrid cloud puzzles. This needs to be done in a controller-agnostic fashion to let automation and orchestration code be free of ties to a specific solution. The networking-bgpvpn project has been kickstarted in the Neutron stadium in 2015 to address this need.
schedule.problem_addressed: The networking-bgpvpn project addresses the goal of being able to use Neutron to create interconnections with BGP/MPLS VPNs outside Openstack.

slides.name: Interconnecting Neutron and Network Operators' BGP VPNs

schedule.title: Interconnecting Neutron and Network Operators' BGP VPNs

videos.name: Interconnecting Neutron and Network Operators' BGP VPNs

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Best practices in tuning Magnum to serve large user base, and best practices in configuring Kubernetes, Swarm, Mesos through Magnum.
schedule.description:
Kubernetes, Swarm and Mesos have been shown to scale to hundreds or thousands of nodes and tens of thousands of containers, handling millions of requests per second. On OpenStack, they can be easily deployed and managed by Magnum, but how do they scale? Building the correct infrastructure plays a critical role in the performance and scalability for the containers, and this needs to be implemented in Magnum.

Working toward this goal, we have built a collection of Rally plugins to track the performance and scalability of both Magnum and the Container Orchestration Engines (Kubernetes, Swarms, Mesos). We have been running the benchmarks on large OpenStack environments to collect measurements and study the behavior of the system. In this talk, we will present our findings along with some of the best practices we found for operating large container environments.
schedule.problem_addressed: Container service for large user base and large environment
schedule.title: Toward 10,000 Containers on OpenStack

videos.name: Toward 10,000 Containers on OpenStack

schedule.description: Join the OpenStack API working group to discuss recently added guidelines, guidelines we need, challenges facing API developers and users in the OpenStack community and anything else relevant to the use of HTTP-based APIs and OpenStack. This will be an informal and mostly unstructed gathering to shape future work and gather input from anyone in the community. There will be a brief overview of what the group has done in the past year but most of the time will be spent planning future direction. This is your chance to shape a part of OpenStack that everything and everyone uses.
schedule.title: API Working Group Meetup

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Diverse perspectives around the importance of diversity in driving OpenStack forward in the future.

2. Insights into successes & opportunities for improvement.

3. Ways for newcomers to get involved & participate.
schedule.description: The incredible spirit of open source and a community-driven development approach has spawned one of the fastest-growing open source communities in the world, with over 54,000 members across 180 countries now contributing to the OpenStack platform in some form. While there is strength in numbers, there is also strength in diversity of viewpoints and perspectives, fundamental to guiding the future of OpenStack and ensuring its vitality. Join us for a captivating session that features TED-style talks from inspiring individuals within the OpenStack community who will share their experiences and insights, and help ease the path for others to join us on our journey. Potential speakers include individuals from EMC, Comcast, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Rackspace, SanDisk, and SUSE.
schedule.problem_addressed: To ensure OpenStack's long-term vitality will require a diversity of viewpoints and perspectives. This session aims to share experiences & insights gained within the OpenStack community -- both, successes & opportunities for improvement. This session also aims to grow diversity within the community by welcoming newcomers into the community.
schedule.social_description: Inspiring the Future of OpenStack Through Diversity
schedule.title: Inspiring the Future of OpenStack Through Diversity

videos.name: Inspiring the Future of OpenStack Through Diversity

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to choose appropriate deployment tool (Fuel, TripleO, Ansible, Puppet, Helion) for OpenStack.

How to implement Neutron SDN/NFV plugin for Service Provider.

How to solve Day 2 Operation for OpenStack private cloud in effective way.

How you should divide steps for implementation of open source private cloud in enterprise service provider.

How implement DevOps workflow in standard enterprise Service Provider.
schedule.description:
Tieto is the #1 cloud service provider in Northern Europe with over 150 cloud customers in the region. Turnover is approximately €1.5 billion.

Chronicle our journey to a new operational meta for our OpenStack cloud. From humble beginnings, follow our path to operational freedom and the security of knowing that every change is proven and can be deployed safely at any time. See how we’ve built on the OpenStack-salt project along with utilizing CI/CD pipelines to allow upstream bug fixes, security patching, service lifecycle management all off a git commit. The session will feature live demos so come prepared to be blown away.
schedule.problem_addressed: There exists tens of deployment tools for OpenStack and it is almost impossible to choose right way without any experience. In this session we will presents our problems during implementation of OpenStack and SDN/NFV solutin in big Service Provider company comes from VMware and legacy infrastructure environment.

slides.name: OpenStack Journey in Tieto Elastic Cloud

schedule.title: OpenStack Journey in Tieto Elastic Cloud

videos.name: OpenStack Journey in Tieto Elastic Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Our session is for attendees who want to know the strategy of obtaining users in your OpenStack systems, or who want to learn the experiences of migration operation support systems/business support systems.

 Thanks to the community, it becomes easier to manage and work OpenStack stably; however, there is still less information about ensuring in-house users, and difficult to know what functions are wanted by potential users. We are going to share our experiences and own tools developed through the migration of miscellaneous NTT DOCOMO's systems. Also, we share future challenges to make the private cloud functions more deeper.
schedule.description: Summit Tokyo, we've reported how DevOps works in our project (http://bit.ly/2a8atnJ) and what kind of operations are performed behind our private cloud system (http://bit.ly/29Dw8FW). Over the first stage of launching private cloud system, now we are aiming to migrate various systems included NTT DOCOMO's basic operation systems to our private cloud. To gather various systems into the one private cloud system enable us to reduce total cost of ownership. Today, we talk our strategy and technical knowledge to expand and deepen our private for the migration.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Our presentation is roughly organized by 4 keywords shown in following.

  1. L2 Gateway
    One of the most important functional  change between our private cloud and operating systems is to create an intranet cloud system. We share our experience and problems in this case.
  2. Reference Model
    To achieve our strict security governance through system architecture on our private cloud, It has been necessary for users to perform various security tasks by themselves. We created the framework with open source software, called "Reference Model", which automatically produces web-oriented architecture based on security rules.
  3.  Automation on Security Update
    As our private cloud expands, We have faced with more and more security vulnerabilities through daily operation. We created an automatic tool for security updates, and share the some custom scripts for automatic Security Updates.
  4. GPU instances
    We launched GPU instances, and learned some tips before running them.
schedule.title: Expanding and Deepening NTT DOCOMO's Private Cloud

videos.name: Expanding and Deepening NTT DOCOMO's Private Cloud

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
A story of learning and experimenting with containers and openstack services 
Tying together container and vm networks under same networking paradigm
schedule.description:
During this session BBVA’s innovation department will give an update on how it is transforming its OpenStack infrastructure to become fully containerized. They selected Kubernetes as a platform for dynamic lifecycle management, to quickly stop/start OpenStack services and place them where desired. From a networking perspective they are leveraging the overlay technology of Nuage Networks, that has intimately worked with them to model both OpenStack’s infrastructure networks as the VM networks as overlay networks into a homogenous networking space.

What is the problem or use case you’re addressing in this session? 

Over the last years, BBVA realized that there was significant effort involved in running, maintaining and upgrading the different OpenStack services. When they realized container/Docker technology could be very beneficial for this, they went for the challenge and revised their architecture to become fully containerized and to virtualize their infrastructure networks.
schedule.title: Innovation at BBVA: Next Generation Overlay for Kubernetes and OpenStack

videos.name: Innovation at BBVA: Next Generation Overlay for Kubernetes and OpenStack

schedule.description: Hearing a lot about OpenStack and want to check it out for yourself? See how quick and easy it is to install start using OpenStack using containers running within a VM on your own laptop, or if you prefer, within a sandbox provided for you. OpenStack Kolla provides production ready tools to deploy OpenStack services as Docker containers that can be managed and upgraded easily. To help you explore Kolla and OpenStack, we provide access to a VM with a containerized deployment of OpenStack Mitaka and step by step instructions. Acquaint yourself with the environment. Learn your way around Horizon (GUI) and the CLI to view and operate your OpenStack cloud. Best of all, take what you learn with you and experiment on your own to discover all OpenStack offers you.
schedule.title: Hands on with Containerized Deployment of OpenStack

schedule.description:
With the advent of multi-cloud initiatives in the enterprise, the complexity of managing private cloud such as OpenStack with one or more public clouds has grown in recent years. Businesses are challenged with “cloud sprawl” – not knowing size and growth of their cloud, and the spend on cloud could soar if not managed well.

Come learn what Talligent has to offer. We will showcase Talligent’s Openbook solution on how to manage a multi-cloud environment on OpenStack, and supporting public clouds Amazon’s AWS and Google’s GCP. This includes billing, chargeback, and capacity planning reporting and analysis for OpenStack and hybrid cloud environments.
schedule.title: Talligent: Hybrid Cloud Management with Talligent Openbook: Come See How We Are Enabling the Journey to Hybrid Cloud on OpenStack

videos.name: Talligent: Hybrid Cloud Management with Talligent Openbook: Come See How We Are Enabling the Journey to Hybrid Cloud on OpenStack

schedule.description:
In this talk, we present OpenSON, a fully SDN-based networking solution, which implements OpenStack networking on virtual switches in compute nodes without a network node. Network functions such as DHCP, SNAT, DNAT and L3 routing are typically executed on a network node in a traditional OpenStack environment. OpenSON, however, eliminates the dependency on the network node by implementing those functions as distributed flow rules on virtual switches in the compute nodes hosting relevant virtual machines. As a result, this approach supports better L3 scalability and high availability.

Moreover, the SDN-based networking approach enables to integrate the control of both overlay networks for virtual networking and underlying physical networks, which enhances the network visibility and facilitates the introduction of network applications such as network monitoring.
schedule.title: No More Network Node: "OpenSON" Fully SDN-Based OpenStack Networking

schedule.description:
CCIB

  • P0 - Marketplace
  • P2 - Banquet Hall

Hilton

  • P0 - Ballroom Foyer

AC Hotel 

  • P4 - Restaurantes Dia y Nit
  • P4 - Sagrada Familia
schedule.title: Lunch (click for details)

schedule.description:
SPEC Cloud (TM) IaaS 2016 is the first industry standard benchmark to measure the performance of public and private IaaS clouds. Designed by a consortium of companies in cloud computing, the benchmark measures the scalability, elasticity, and mean instance provisioning time of a cloud.

Whether you are looking to measure the performance of your cloud, evaluating different configurations for their underlying performance, SPEC Cloud IaaS 2016 can provide a meaningful and reproducible way to measure performance.

In this talk, the attendees will learn:

  • What is SPEC Cloud IaaS 2016?
  • What are the key metrics it measures?
  • How to publish a result using SPEC Cloud IaaS 2016?
  • How to evaluate different OpenStack configurations using SPEC Cloud IaaS 2016?
schedule.title: Evaluating OpenStack Performance with the SPEC Cloud (TM) IaaS 2016 Benchmark

schedule.description:
Billions of sensors. Gazillion bytes of data. How can OpenStack Networking manage to scale with IoT endpoints, allow throughput for communication, and all the while keeping traffic flows isolated?

Open source MidoNet enables the solution for IoT networking with OpenStack. With its inherent ability to scale thanks to its distributed architecture, traffic flow visibility has never been easier for workflows in large environments. This demo will highlight the scalability properties of MidoNet and demonstrate the traffic flow visibility through the analytics tool called MidoNet Manager.
schedule.title: Midokura: Scaling IoT with OpenStack Networking and Open Source MidoNet

videos.name: Midokura: Scaling IoT with OpenStack Networking and Open Source MidoNet

schedule.description: OpenStack Foundation Interop Engineer Chris Hoge will give a short demonstration of how you can use standalone OpenStack Ironic, installed with OpenStack Bifrost, to provision your bare-metal hardware infrastructure. On a live cluster, you will see how to create operating system images with OpenStack Disk Image Builder, enroll servers to the Ironic service, then deploy the images directly to the servers with Ironic.
schedule.title: OpenStack Ironic Demo

schedule.description:
OpenStack software development is centered around the Git and Gerrit systems to promote the aspect of community programming.

Git is an open source version control system that allows many software developers to work on a given project without requiring them to share a common network.

Gerrit is a free, web-based team code collaboration tool which integrates closely with Git and allows developers in a team to review each other’s modifications to the source code using a web browser and approve or reject those changes.

In this session we will walk participants through opening a bug in a test system and then submit a patch to a repository in OpenStack. The process involves learning about Git using the most common commands and progressing through the review process in Gerrit. Participants will walk away with a working knowledge of these tools.

Pre-requisites for the session: 
https://github.com/spotzz/barcelonasummit
schedule.title: Git and Gerrit Lunch and Learn

schedule.description:
Cloud Computing is accelerating the movement of System monitoring from manual, to reactive to proactive. One important aspect of being proactive is Anomaly Detection. But, it’s often unclear what’s anomalous for a given deployment. Machine learning techniques can help.

Contrail Networking provides an Anomaly Detection model based on time-series of any metric. Based on past information, we learn what to expect in the future. If a given metric reports values that are far from this expectation, we raise an Alert.

In this example we will use statistical process control, based on computing the running average and standard deviation and examining the current value using real-time stream processing. The metric being used is the number of active flows on the host/vRouter. We run a multitier application with some clients – a redmine webserver with a separate mysql database. Then, we launch a TCP SYN attack on the server, which causes an ususual number of flows. This triggers an Alert.
schedule.title: Anomaly Detection in Contrail Networking

schedule.description:
Identifying broken ends and root causes of issues in cloud infrastructure is becoming challenging. In a typical cloud deployment there are multiple controllers and computes with each of them hosting several services. It is in this mesh of services and nodes where an operations person can easily get lost to identify where the cloud infrastructure is broken. There are lot of logs, tools, external services to examine.

With this cloud inspector, any one would be able to isolate the broken ends and find root cause of issues in the cloud infrastructure. This will enable the people to keep all their services up and running. Also they will be able to meet their committed SLAs.

In this session people will see hands-on session of how things can debugged quickly. I will attempt to resolve one of the most common and tricky error or "No Valid Host found" in various forms to demostrate the advantages of this framework.
schedule.title: Cloud Inspector

schedule.description:
Organisations relying on the rudimentary capabilities for sizing and placing in OpenStack & KVM or third party load balancing tools are unnecessarily introducing risk and inefficiencies into their environments.

Join Andy Walton, Technical Director of Cirba for a discussion of how infrastructure control provides policy-based control over KVM infrastructure through intelligent workload placement decisions.

In this session you will learn:

• How better VM placements enable you to safely increase density by an average of 48%
• How your team can significantly reduce software requirements
• How to gain visibility into actual infrastructure requirements in order to eliminate over-provisioning
schedule.title: Cirba: Optimise OpenStack with Infrastructure Control Analytics for Intelligently Placing and Sizing VMs

videos.name: Cirba: Optimise OpenStack with Infrastructure Control Analytics for Intelligently Placing and Sizing VMs

schedule.description: OpenStack Foundation Interop Engineer Chris Hoge will talk about the Interoperability Working Group (formerly DefCore) and why products with the OpenStack Powered logo assure you of a minimum level of interoperability. This will include information about how vendors and users can test their clouds against the latest interop guidelines and qualify for the OpenStack Powered mark.
schedule.title: Introduction to the OpenStack Powered program and Interoperability

schedule.description:
In order to provide reliable, high-performance, on-demand, cost effective storage for applications hosted on servers, more and more cloud providers and customers are extend their storage to include Solid State drive (SSD).  In this session, you will learn about how to build Ceph based OpenStack storage solutions with today’s SSD as well as future Intel® Optane™ technology, we will:

  • Present two reference architects and data of all SSD Ceph cluster that can deliver greater than 1 million IOPS for the performance intensive environment - providing a more cost effective solution than today’s HDD cluster.
  • Share "good/better/best" system configurations and performance optimization best known methods, and share early Ceph BlueStore performance results with 3D NAND SSD configuration
  • Discuss future Ceph architectures using next generation Intel® Optane™ technology, including proposals of OpenStack Ceph hyper-converged solutions based on Intel® Optane™ technology

slides.name: Delivering High Performance OpenStack Storage Solutions with NVMe SSD and Intel® Optane™ Technology

schedule.title: Delivering High Performance OpenStack Storage Solutions with NVMe SSD and Intel® Optane™ Technology

schedule.description: Cinder is a well-defined interface for managing block storage devices. However, some of the processes are at odds with features on vendors' backend storage devices. This presentation will cover solutions for finding a balance between Cinder volume-centric storage and alternatives such as intent based storage for those looking to integrate Cinder.
schedule.title: Datera: Reconciling Intent Defined Storage with Cinder's Volume-Centric Model

videos.name: Datera: Reconciling Intent Defined Storage with Cinder's Volume-Centric Model

schedule.description: While it is easy to throw together a single Rack Openstack Cluster, scaling out to 20+ Racks with over 300 nodes across 74 zones in combination with Contrail networking can be a real challenge.  In this presentation, we will describe our scale out model, collaborative approach and quality checks using several automation methodologies to deliver high-quality AT&T Integrated Cloud (AIC) zones. AIC is an Openstack Based Cloud Platform consolidating several disparate cloud instances under one umbrella. The use case covers driving consistency across required size differences and environment types which included data centers, network technical centers, central offices and video hub offices.  How to rapidly deploy cloud software across many global sites to meet customer demands with high quality zones. How several unique automation methods and best practices were used in a large scale deployment.
schedule.title: Overcoming Deployment Challenges: High Quality Deliveries Quickly

schedule.description:
Storage self-service is one of the important tenets of modernizing IT. Storage provisioning typically takes days to weeks time due to the complex approval processes and application requirements getting translated into storage capabilities. Service providers aim to achieve agility, operational efficiency and improved service levels by allowing application and server teams to provision their own storage, on-demand. It allows the storage team to free up critical resources and improves operational efficiency, while maintaining IT control via policies to avoid any erroneous self-service errors.
In this talk we present how we have used Openstack successfully to enable self servicing and API based automated storage provisioning for one of the largest service provider (IBM Global Technology Services). We will share the lessons learnt from the perspective of IT service provider and many customers across the globe on what has worked well vs what did not work as expected.
schedule.title: Enabling a Policy-Driven, Self-Service Storage Provisioning Control Plane for a Service Provider

schedule.description:
Nova is doing a retrospective for the Newton release to reflect on what went well and what did not go well, and what, if anything, we can learn and improve. Not specific to the Newton release but the speed of development (features) and technical debt, specifically around having a huge repo with a ton of proposed changes but a relatively small active core team, always comes up. At various times different people have proposed different ideas on how to fix the code review latency issue. Ideas include simply scaling the core reviewer team (not having such a high bar to entry), decomposing the repo (breaking out the virt drivers), and subsystem maintainers (people with +2 in certain areas or features of code, but not +2 on the entire repo). This session is really meant to be a discussion between PTLs and core reviewers on various projects to see what ideas teams have tried and what has worked and what has not worked. For example, Neutron did the stadium to mixed results - but unless you are an active developer on Neutron you maybe do not know the details, so what happened?

References: Nova Newton retrospective etherpad

Session Leader(s): Matt Riedemann (mriedem), Steve Martinelli (stevemar), Doug Hellmann (dhellmann)
schedule.title: Cross Project Workshops: Experiences with Project Decomposition, Scaling Review Teams and Subsystem Maintainers (Part 2)

schedule.description:
A variety of OpenStack projects have drivers. Nova has hypervisors, Cinder has different block storage implementations it supports, etc. Different projects do verification on these drivers like third-party CI testing. Today the OpenStack Foundation uses the information provided in driver log to provide deployers a list of supported drivers. Unfortunately this information is out of date for quite a few projects, and most don't really have any verification. Some is just verified as being supported because it's in tree. Some are on this list and not even an upstream driver. The session goal is to talk about the current state of driver log, who is reviewing it, and how things should be validated.

References: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/driverlog-validation

Session Leader(s): Mike Perez (thingee)
schedule.title: Cross Project Workshops: Driver Log Validation

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn why the challenges exist, what are the technologies available today, and new technologies that are being defined.
schedule.description:
Service function chaining (SFC) is the underpinning of NFV, enabling operators to compose a dynamic sequence of network services suited for elastic service environments that ultimately determines the quality and efficiency of service offerings. Virtualized network functions is one step in the NFV journey, but they are insufficient without proper SFC.In this session, the panel of CTOS will discuss technologies that are available today and in development for the near future to drive more agile, dynamic SFC with granular service points and policies for OpenStack operators. Some topics to be discussed will include:  

  • Role of SFC in NFV  
  • Challenges of deploying SFC
  • Clarifying SFC, Service Insertion, Service Graphs
  • SFC Architecture Framework
  • Standards bodies: ETSI, IETF on SFC
  • SFC working groups and where to find more information
schedule.problem_addressed: The problems addressed include challenges of deploying SFC, how OpenStack operators can overcome those challenges.
schedule.title: CTO Perspectives on Service Function Chaining for OpenStack Clouds

videos.name: CTO Perspectives on Service Function Chaining for OpenStack Clouds

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how to coordinate QoS across the cloud infrastructure for maximum effect.
schedule.description:
Quality of Service (QoS) is typically associated with networking, however it can be applied to all components that make up the cloud infrastructure (i.e. compute, network and storage).  In fact, unless a cloud-wide approach to QoS is taken, enabling QoS features may not have much of an effect on performance.

This session will explore the QoS features that are currently available or upcoming in OpenStack, with an eye toward coordinating QoS across the entire cloud infrastructure in order to ensure that the cloud will meet the demands of critical applications.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to ensure that critical applications get the cloud resources they need to run efficiently.

slides.name: QoS QoS Baby

schedule.title: QoS QoS Baby

videos.name: QoS QoS Baby

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the benifits of managing OpenStack with Kubernetes through its unique abstraction layer.
schedule.description:
OpenStack consists of interrelated software components that control hardware pools of processing, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter that are difficult to install, manage, and upgrade. With Kubernetes, each of the services can be viewed as applications.  Combined, they form a complex application that Kubernetes is capable of managing.

Kubernetes provides high-level abstractions built around the needs of complex production systems like OpenStack. This provides an alternative approach to operations enabling clusters to be more easily operated, managed, and automated. In addition, Kubernetes has native tooling which simplifies otherwise hard problems like HA or upgrades.

In this talk, the kolla-k8s team will demonstrate how Kubernetes solves the "Day 1" problem of deployment as well as "Day 2" operations like configuration, reconfiguration, failure recovery, and upgrades.  We will also demonstrate a production ready, highly available OpenStack based on kolla-k8s.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack consists of interrelated software components that control hardware pools of processing, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter that are difficult to install, manage, and upgrade. With Kubernetes, each of the services can be viewed as applications.  Combined, they form a complex application that Kubernetes is capable of managing.
schedule.title: OpenStack is an Application! Deploy and Manage Your Stack with Kolla-Kubernetes

videos.name: OpenStack is an Application! Deploy and Manage Your Stack with Kolla-Kubernetes

schedule.description:
In this session, learn about how Fujitsu has made improvements to Neutron to make it globally-scalable and enterprise-ready.

Through many years’ experience of delivering on-premise and cloud-based solutions that support the mission-critical services and applications of large enterprises, Fujitsu has been able to identify improvements to OpenStack (Neutron in particular) for more effective enterprise usage.

Discover how we are making these improvements a reality to achieve outcomes such as:

  • Reliability for zero downtime
  • Detecting issues and rapid troubleshooting
  • Robust Security of ‘must-not-fail’ applications
schedule.title: Fujitsu: Enhancement of Neutron for Enterprise Usage

videos.name: Fujitsu: Enhancement of Neutron for Enterprise Usage

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn vendor-neutral methods to secure OpenStack clouds (and other complex systems) using a holistic strategy.

 

This starts with an introduction to the concept of compartmentalized security in an OpenStack environment. Attendees will learn how to analyze a complex system, understand the sensitivity of data and where that data is stored.


Attendees will see how these compartments interact with each other and how to apply security policy to these interactions.  That will lead into a discussion around implementing useful security controls that are scalable and repeatable.
schedule.description:
Nothing clears out a conference room faster than a discussion around information security. Securing complex computer systems, such as OpenStack clouds, is extremely difficult. To make matters worse, attackers can make many mistakes without consequences. A defender’s single mistake could lead to a breach.

Don't let fear rule the discussion around security.

Operators need a simple and scalable method for securing OpenStack clouds. That starts with grouping components into compartments and then looking at how those compartments interact with each other. Those interactions form the backbone of security policies and technical controls.

In this vendor-neutral talk, Major Hayden, principal architect at Rackspace, will break down the complexity of securing OpenStack clouds using real-world scenarios. Attendees will learn how to:

  • Divide OpenStack deployments into compartments
  • Analyze the interactions between each component
  • Develop security policies and apply technical controls
schedule.problem_addressed:
OpenStack clouds are complex systems and securing these systems requires a deep understanding of the interactions in the environment. However, OpenStack is made up of many smaller systems that can be grouped and handled in similar ways.


The basis of holistic medicine is that the human body is a mass of interconnected systems that must be reviewed as a whole but also inspected at a lower level. A deficiency in one area may show up as a problem somewhere else. Security teams can use this same strategy to tackle information security challenges in OpenStack clouds.
schedule.title: Holistic Security for OpenStack Clouds

videos.name: Holistic Security for OpenStack Clouds

schedule.description:
Openstack is a multi-layered cloud infrastructure with many complex internal and external dependencies. Hence, when the system is troubled, you need to run multiple commands and check different areas before you can define where to perform a deep dive troubleshooting.

The objective here is to shorten the initial investigation and focus on the most probable cause of the issue.

This is leveraging the knowledge accumulated by escalation engineers while managing real customer environments running Openstack.
Kibana and ElasticSearch also simplify the troubleshooting by making log search and analysis fast and easy.

We will cover how they can be used in a distributed system and integrated with OpenStack.

We will demonstrate the capabilities of the Kibana user interface - searching logs, trending issues, exporting log files and more.

Finally, we will provide examples of cases where Kibana was used to analyze and solve real world issues in OpenStack.
schedule.title: Dell EMC: Accelerate the OpenStack RCA and Leverage Kibana/ElasticSearch

videos.name: Dell EMC: Accelerate the OpenStack RCA and Leverage Kibana/ElasticSearch

schedule.description:
Enterprise companies around the world are continuing to adopt OpenStack. In this session, hear about two separate use cases from two companies who chose OpenStack and IBM to help deliver their solution.

Materna, a leading IT consulting and managed service provider company in Europe, will share their use case and the criteria they used for choosing OpenStack as the foundation for their customer-facing solutions. You will hear why they selected an "as a service" deployment model for OpenStack and chose IBM Blue Box to help them innovate faster with the benefits of an open cloud.

AT&T will review a use case for geo-distributed Swift object store deployments at scale. With its Domain 2.0 effort, AT&T is a big proponent of open source software and hardware.  You will hear about AT&T’s Proof of concept testing with IBM and OpenPOWER to provide an open hardware and open source software object storage solution with benefits in density and performance.
schedule.title: IBM: Don't Just Take Our Word for It: Use Cases from Materna & AT&T

videos.name: IBM: Don't Just Take Our Word for It: Use Cases from Materna & AT&T

schedule.description: An informal gathering for people interested in the Scientific Working Group to discuss OpenStack's new capabilities for research computing applications and to share information on how OpenStack can be configured to deliver on the requirements of research computing.
schedule.title: Scientific Working Group BOF

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In the presentation, you will get an overview of how to serve TensorFlow upon OpenStack as the deep learning plaform. We will share the experiences of how to integrate TensorFlow to OpenStack efficiently.
schedule.description: TensorFlow was a new open source platform for artificial intelligence by Google Brain Team. Because of its powerful features and high scalability, it gains extensive attention once open source. In the other hand, as the most widely used cloud platform, thousands of organisations host their data processing platforms on OpenStack with Sahara project. Can we bring TensorFlow together with OpenStack?
schedule.problem_addressed: There are two distinct procedures of machine learning tasks: Training and Serving. After TensorFlow 0.8, it fully support distributed training, and once we got the trained model, it can deploy to production in a cluster for serving. Both two procedures are natural supported by Kubernetes. And as we know, OpenStack is able to manage Kubernetes with Magnum project. So how we integrated the TensorFlow and OpenStack? Should we based on Sahara or Magnum or both? This session will give a brief introduction of TensorFlow, the distribution model of TensorFlow, discuss the best practices for integrating it to OpenStack, and give a demo of how this powerful deep learning platform to benefit from OpenStack managed cloud infrastructure.

slides.name: Build the Artificial Intelligence Cloud - Provision and Manage TensorFlow cluster with OpenStack

schedule.title: Build the Artificial Intelligence Cloud - Provision and Manage TensorFlow cluster with OpenStack

videos.name: Build the Artificial Intelligence Cloud - Provision and Manage TensorFlow cluster with OpenStack

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We expect attendees will :

1. Learn about the Existing Overcommit techniques in various hypervisors and how they work

2. Learn about various  techniques like Ballooning, KSM, Memory Compression and Transcendent memory.

3. Learn how to dynamically expand and contract VMs

4. Learn how to make Openstack to operate at maximum efficiency with minimum resources
schedule.description:
In a multi-tenanted Enterprise Cloud deployment, every now and then, we face a situation where we wished we had more compute resource to service new requirements. Since capacity planning is not a fool-proof prediction of your growth, facing a resource crunch situation is inevitable. To mitigate this challenge, in this presentation, we will showcase techniques which you can use to run your cloud at maximum efficiency.

We will showcase how to make the entire deployment elastic by innovatively expanding and contracting memory / CPU overcommits without penalising performance.
schedule.problem_addressed: Despite capacity planning, very often cloud operators have to deal with sporadic growth requirements and end up losing customers due to resource crunch or result in poor performance of running workloads. Not every workload utilises the resources they are entitled to and there are some workloads which perform poorly due to crunch. Our presentation specifically addresses these challenges by providing new techniques to resource overcommits.
schedule.title: Get More Juice out of Your Cloud - Dynamic Over Provisioning Techniques

videos.name: Get More Juice out of Your Cloud - Dynamic Over Provisioning Techniques

schedule.description: Looking for Meeting Room space for the AUC
schedule.title: AUC Working Group

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Reviewing a manual test scenario
  • Creating a Tempest plugin
  • Implementing a scenario test based on manual test script
  • Installing the Tempest plugin into a Rally deployment.
  • Running the test, viewing and comparing test results via Rally.
schedule.description:
Testing an OpenStack deployment by running 100s of detailed manual test scripts is a very time consuming effort.  Luckily, the Tempest test framework has a plugin interface and scenario test framework that can be leveraged for automating detailed test scenarios.


In addition to standard scenario test, that drive the OpenStack REST APIs, it is also possible to create scenario tests utilizing the WebDriver API for simulating browser interaction with Horizon, for full end-to-end UI test scenarios.


Furthermore, a Tempest plugin can be installed into a Rally deployment, so you can leverage the power of Rally for persisting your test runs , as well as create reports and compare test runs etc.


This presentation will outline and demonstrate the entire process for automating a single detailed test scenario.
schedule.problem_addressed: Migrating manual test suite to an automated on via a Tempest plugin.
schedule.title: Automating Your Manual Test Suite Using a Tempest Plugin, Scenario Tests and Rally

videos.name: Automating Your Manual Test Suite Using a Tempest Plugin, Scenario Tests and Rally

schedule.description:
As the number of production OpenStack deployments increase and more ecosystem partners add support for OpenStack clouds, it becomes increasingly important that the communities building services around OpenStack guide and influence the product evolution. The OpenStack User Committee mission is to:

  • Consolidate user requirements and present these to the management board and technical committee
  • Provide guidance for the development teams where user feedback is requested
  • Track OpenStack deployments and usage, helping to share user stories and experiences
  • Work with the user groups worldwide to keep the OpenStack community vibrant and informed

If you are interested in volunteering to help with User Committee efforts, please join us!
schedule.title: User Commitee Session

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

  • The role of IP/MPLS Controllers in modern SP networks
  • The role of DC Controllers in modern DCs
  • The value of standardized information models for the sharing of domain specific information
  • The cloud is not just someone else’s computer but rather a complex entity with his own traffic engineering requirements
  • Requirements for seamless Traffic Engineering and potential solutions
  • The relationship with Openstack/Neutron and common SDN-Controllers
schedule.description:
Several models for providing end-to-end traffic engineering between data-centers in carrier backbone networks through the interworking of Data-center(DC) and WAN SDN Controller will be presented. The model will enable seamless end-to-end service and traffic engineering from host to host and/or ToR to ToR across large National Service Provider backbones. A number of use-cases including the dynamic provisioning of virtual resources in Data Center as well as logical resources in transport network will be covered.  Options such as DC SDN Controller to WAN SDN Controller coupling with abstract Interface definition or extension of an unified control plane which spans the Datacenter and Backbone Networks will be discussed along with advantages and disadvantages of the options.

The direct sharing of information, via standardized information models, between SDN Controllers will result in improvements in efficiency, flexibility and improved elasticity of resources for modern Carrier Networks.
schedule.problem_addressed: The current challenge of today’s Cloud Architecture is the focusing on a single instance environment.   There is often a belief that a “cloud” is a single instance rather than a combination of many instances, i.e. multiple Data Centers, connected by multiple WANs. Today’s Traffic Engineering scope does not account for an end-to-end service, rather it’s based on Traffic Engineering within separated domains, i.e. a Backbone domain or a Data Center domain). Real end-to-end Traffic Engineering from an Openstack managed VM “A1” inside Datacenter “A” to VM “B1” inside Datacenter “B”, across a WAN(s) or Service Provider Network(s) requires an end-to-end view.
schedule.title: From Neutron to Neutron: SDN-Driven Backbone Traffic Engineering

videos.name: From Neutron to Neutron: SDN-Driven Backbone Traffic Engineering

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn what the different measurements mean and how they can use them to get meaningful information and also have feedback about how they are progressing. The talk will provide information to both managers and developers by showing how they can interpret the same information in their own field to get the expected outcome and get closer to their goals.
schedule.description:
Measuring progress, effectiveness and success is a key in every organization from software development to services. The metrics are the same, and as always the devil is in the details.

In an open source environment the different actors need to use the same set of numbers to form a meaningful set of KPIs. As the traditional processes and ways of working go through a transformation period to adjust to open source methods, it is crucial to have the same changes applied to metrics and how they are used to get the proper feedback loop.

This presentation will go through the existing tools that provide measurements and describe the meaning of each. The presentation will also give an overview on how to use the values in an efficient way to become drivers of both business and development as opposed to a numbers' game.
schedule.problem_addressed: There are a large set of metrics measured and available publicly. When these metrics are not used in the proper way that can affect business and development strategy, presence in the community and community engagement. This talk intends to clarify what the available metrics mean and how they can effectively used.
schedule.title: Metrics: Friends or Enemies?

videos.name: Metrics: Friends or Enemies?

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will be able to learn the essential parts and real world practices of running OpenStack operations and an OpenStack operations team, especially for the organization that is new to OpenStack world.
schedule.description: Every cloud lover is running the same OpenStack, but different people deploy and operate OpenStack in different ways. In this session we'd like to share our practices to ramp up an efficient OpenStack operations team, based on real-world experiences and retrospection from operating dedicated and local OpenStack clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed:
We are going to introduce the following OpenStack operations practices:

  • Everything as a Code, other than "Infrastructure as a Code". Use git to control even your operation runbooks. This will not only promote automation, but also force people to do things in simple ways (as putting Word documents into git will be silly).
  • Use Configuration Management tools for any cloud change, not only for deployment/update, but also for daily operations. This will force more automation into the team with less SSH ops.
  • Centralized Collaboration as ChatOps. Put everything into Slack and build up your operations workflows into ChatOps rather than using it just as a chat tool.
  • Carefully define the shifts, to help with both the SLA and the easier life of your operators. 
  • Essential processes for OpenStack Operations, including Incident Management, Change Management, etc.

slides.name: OpenStack Operations Quick Ramp-up and Survival Guide

schedule.title: OpenStack Operations Quick Ramp-up and Survival Guide

videos.name: OpenStack Operations Quick Ramp-up and Survival Guide

schedule.description:
RSVP REQUIRED: https://susetraining.eventbrite.com


This training is a two day course spread across three days - 1/2 day on Tuesday, 1/2 day on Wednesday, full day on Thursday. Participants must attend all days in order to complete the course. (The course is spread across three days to allow attends the opportunity to attend other sessions at the conference in addition to this training). 

Attendees must have a Full Access pass to the OpenStack Summit Barcelona in order to attend this training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This course is designed for system administrators and others who want to learn how to administer an OpenStack Cloud. Participants receive a comprehensive understanding of the tasks necessary to administer an OpenStack cloud and then use common tools that are included with an OpenStack distribution to administer a SUSE OpenStack cloud. This course prepares the participants to take and pass the Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) exam.
schedule.title: RSVP Required: SUSE Three-Day Training: OpenStack Administration - Prepare for the Certified Exams

schedule.description:
Among the key findings of a recent survey by the OpenStack Foundation was a strong interest among OpenStack users in software-based networking on servers, or server-based networking. But the rapid evolution of cloud-based data centers to support virtualized services in multi-tenant environments requires an increasingly rich set of functionality in the server-based networking data path to support things such as overlay tunneling, distributed security, service chaining, and flow based analytics. This increasing functionality, coupled with ever-increasing speeds and feeds, all while maintaining the flexibility for change, creates the need for a new type of solution: the SmartNIC.

There has been a lot of buzz in the industry regarding the use of SmartNICs, also known as intelligent server adapters, in cloud datacenter servers to boost performance by offloading servers from having to perform server-based network data path processing. But what exactly is the definition of a SmartNIC anyway? What are the different models for SmartNIC offload for server-based networking? What are some examples for functions that can be offloaded to the SmartNIC, and how much benefit can be realized over purely software-based approaches? What are some examples of real-life use cases that can benefit from SmartNIC acceleration and offload?

This marketplace theater segment will provide a discussion with answers to these questions, and leave you with a better understanding of SmartNICs, their benefits, and their usage in OpenStack cloud networks.
schedule.title: Netronome: Accelerating Server Based Networking in the OpenStack Cloud Using SmartNICs

videos.name: Netronome: Accelerating Server Based Networking in the OpenStack Cloud Using SmartNICs

schedule.description: This  talk examines how containers use OpenStack networking in order to  be able to provide containers with netwoking capabilities, and how containers are different from VMs from a networking vantage point.  We look at what the needs of container networks, how those needs can be achieved, and what trade-offs have to be made.  We will dive into some  specific container networking solutions, but the talk is primarily intended to introduce people to the higher level techologies that container  networking uses, and what the future for container networking might hold.  Only beginner-level knowledge of networking will be assumed, and by the end of the talk you should have a better understanding of how OpenStack and container networking works together.
schedule.title: Intro to Integrating Containers with OpenStack Networking

schedule.description: Think back to the days when you could go online and custom order your server. The vendor could hold little inventory, assembling on the fly. Similarly, think of a pool of disaggregated hardware (storage, compute, and networking), from which nodes can be dynamically composed and attached or detached from a cloud customized to a workload. A node for storage would be composed with more Solid State Devices than one for compute. We introduce RedFish API and Intel Rack Scale Design Extensions. We highlight its abilities to compose, boot, monitor, power on and off, create VLANs via the API without directly logging into the Switch. We next share the solution which integrates with Fuel, to deploy an OpenStack cloud and our motivation to develop “RSC” as a project, working with Fuel, Juju, and TripleO, to realize the vision of SDI. You can dynamically grow and shrink clouds, through plugins in Nova, Ironic, Horizon and policies in Congress for increased load or quiet spells.
schedule.title: Software Defined Infrastructure Using RackScale Design for the Under-Cloud

schedule.description:
As enterprises embrace cloud, they are increasingly looking at options to put some of their workloads on public cloud. Managing multi-cloud environment has been a necessary evil. It usually introduces complexity and results in vendor lock-in.

In this talk, we present the use of the OpenStack API layer as the unifying interface for multi-cloud management. In our experience we found that OpenStack API is expressive and powerful. It is able to solve a number of use cases related to managing workloads on public cloud like AWS.

We extended the OpenStack control pane by building AWS-specific drivers for Nova, Glance, Cinder and Neutron as a solution to the hybrid cloud complexity. We have included Platform9’s brownfield discovery technology to further ease the ingestion of AWS workloads into an OpenStack-driven cloud.

This approach provides a powerful hybrid cloud solution, enabling organizations to standardize on an open standard and reuse the tooling around it for public cloud resources.
schedule.title: Platform9: Using OpenStack to Control AWS

videos.name: Platform9: Using OpenStack to Control AWS

schedule.description: Data is transforming every sector of the economy and all aspects of society. Customers are collecting more data, storing large volumes of data, and at times required to archive data. In this session, learn about how Cisco’s UCS C3260 Storage Server enables data storage with Ceph to be the enabling application-influenced platform designed for a variety of data intensive workloads offering industry-leading density, scalability, and economics. C3260 was designed from the ground up for Object Stores and is ideally suited as a Ceph or SWIFT back-up device. Learn about how Cisco customers today are deploying Ceph on the C3260 for mission critical data center storage as a service platform.
schedule.title: Colusa - Cisco UCS C3260 and Ceph for Object Stores

schedule.description:
Running a Working Group which represents one of the many users of the OpenStack community is not a trivial task, especially when best practices with regards to the open principles are observed.  This session will be lead by the User Committee and attended by Working Group chairs to discuss "good practice" in how to run a working group which has been approved by the User-Committee.  

Proposed agenda items:

  • Goal setting methodologies by chairs for each cycle, buy-in, tracking, deliverable, shared ownership by WG. 
  • User Committee engagement with WGs and leadership role of UC.
    • Good practice for running F2F meetings at Summit: 2-3 session to assure outcomes, social gatherings, etc.
    • Recruitment of new members.
    • Timezones and cultural considerations.
    • International perception and foreign language member participation.
    • Communication between WG co-chairs and UC chairs.
    • Input by WGs into Blueprints, working with the TC/PTLs in cycle planning.
  • Sub-teams/activities in WGs and/or new WGs... to sub-WG or not to sub-WG... aka WG scope.
  • Joint midcycles with other WGs?  Organised by the UC?
  • Co-located WG meetings, i.e. WGs with overlapping membership to meet after one another?
    • WG Co-Chairs: different regions and remits? EU+USA+APAC?
    • WG meeting preparation: calendar items, call for agenda items, use of etherpads, wiki updates, email to user-committee, agreed open meeting channel (voice vs irc), etc
  • WG meeting runtime: irc meeting bot, agenda with note taking, recorded actions, reminder of overall objectives for cycle, etc
  • WG post-meeting remit: summary of meeting posted to user-committee mailing list, list of follow up actions per member name and suggested ETA, etc.

Primary Audience
Working Group Chairs and Regular WG attendees.

 

Secondary Audience
Any community member looking to participate and/or hep organise a user-committee working group.
schedule.title: Efficiency of Working Groups - Working Together to Advance the Community Leadership of the User Committee

schedule.description: After releasing our bare-metal offering based on OpenStack's Ironic, we had a choice to make regarding our current customers’ existing product and services. Being hell-bent on providing them with long term, viable solutions, we decided to convert as much of their infrastructure as possible to the new platform. From dedicated servers to fully Ironic-managed ones, Maxime Bélanger and Paul Millette will present a process that attendees can follow to convert servers and infrastructure, to adapt network models and to ensure compatibility between the two platforms. They will also walk through the tools developed and used through this conversion process and the challenges faced along the way.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Converging customer into a unified platform so that clients have full OpenStack experience
  • Migrating from custom cloud/baremetal platform to OpenStack
  • Seamless migration in production (no downtime, no impact on the customer)

schedule.description:
Magnum clusters must be acted upon to transition them through various lifecycle states. In this session we will discuss the current cluster lifecycle, and what we would like to add to support the needs of cloud operators offering Container Orchestration Engines (COEs) as part of their hosted cloud services. For example, we plan to have new lifecycle operations for: REBOOT, RESTART, COE_NODE_DRAIN, UPGRADE, and REBUILD. One key decision to make here is how best to allow secure interaction between COEs and OpenStack APIs. We will not discuss the implementation details of cluster upgrades, which will be addressed in a separate session - Magnum: Cluster Upgrades.

See also: Update Spec for trusts.
schedule.title: Magnum: Lifecycle Operations, Cluster Maintenance, and Trust

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the test configuration, scenarios, what worked and what didn’t work so well. Potential production gotchas and areas to explore further will be shared.
schedule.description: The OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC), established by Intel and Rackspace, is created to accelerate adoption of open source cloud operating system while supporting open source principles. OSIC provides ready-to-use data center facilities to the OpenStack community for development and test.  This case study presentation highlights a scale-out test performed within a 3 week period using OpenStack Ansible Community based on Liberty with an SDN overlay network connecting 131 nodes running over 1,000 VMs. Tempest and Rally tests were conducted to validate functions including high availability failure scenarios. Join this session to find out more about OSIC and the SDN scale-out test configuration, scenarios, and results.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session shares the scaling tests conducted in the OSIC lab with insights on Neutron, control plane and data plane test results that will shed light on production scaling needs.
schedule.title: SDN Scale-out Testing at OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC)

videos.name: SDN Scale-out Testing at OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC)

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to hear from the panel of experts that have invested and grown Barcelona's entrepreneurial ecosystem of startups, connecting Spain to the global tech community. They will also hear from European investors that directly invested in OpenStack and containers startups and their funding criteria. This is a must-see for would-be entrepreneurs looking for funding in Europe or for companies looking for partnerships with European startups.
schedule.description:
Startups have always been a critical force in driving innovation in software and platforms. OpenStack and Docker has spawned a vibrant ecosystem of startups that are finding innovative new ways to serve customer needs and deliver value on top of OpenStack and containers. However, access to capital to support development and growth within these companies is sometimes complicated, but also critical.  

This esteemed panel includes both startups that have been successful in attracting essential capital, and ventures capitalists who are actively investing in OpenStack and container technology startups. The panel will have a particular focus on the funding situation and startup scene in Barcelona and more broadly, in Europe.
schedule.problem_addressed: Stories about tech startups closing new rounds of funding are prevalent. Plenty of familiar VC and investment house names season the tech industry. Yet, many great alternatives exist outside of the traditional U.S. tech hubs, especially in Europe. This panel will attempt to shed light on the alternative source of funding outside of traditional U.S. tech hubs, especially in Europe and right here in Barcelona. The panel will share best practices on how to connect with the European VC community and also with the U.S. giants that may have extension operations outside of US.
schedule.title: Building Your Technology Castell, Cloud Startup Funding Scene in Europe

videos.name: Building Your Technology Castell, Cloud Startup Funding Scene in Europe

schedule.description:
Using Bare Metal (BM) and Virtual Machines (VM) in one environment presents many challenges. For example, whilst Bare Metal services are necessary for enterprise systems in order to satisfy performance requirements and in many on-premise cases, enable cloud migration, Bare Metal servers can lack the flexibility delivered by VMs.

In this session with Fujitsu, discover how:

  • Bare Metal and Virtual Machines can be used simultaneously and managed via one platform acting as a ‘single pane of glass’
  • Fujitsu is working towards providing Bare Metal servers with the same level of flexibility as Virtual Machines
  • Fujitsu is contributing to the Ironic project and Newton release to fill the ‘gaps’ that exist between Bare Metal and Virtual Machines
schedule.title: Fujitsu: The Ironic Story: Filling the Gap Between Bare Metal and Virtual Machines… New Features in Newton and Future Plans

videos.name: Fujitsu: The Ironic Story: Filling the Gap Between Bare Metal and Virtual Machines… New Features in Newton and Future Plans

schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Get real life information and practical advice from an operations of a large organization and hear the success stories of the journey to cloud and OpenStack
  • The challenges a traditional IT team may run into with all the shiny new things like DevOps, agile development, cloud paradigms and methodology
  • Advice on how to cope with objections from traditional organizations and processes
  • Lessons learned about changes and (self-) transformations needed to benefit from cloud technologies and methodologies
  • Learn about a successful operational approach regarding OpenStack, the ecosystem around it, and the services & solutions a cloud consumer is interested in when using private IaaS & PaaS from an internal private cloud
schedule.description:
Originally, the Group IT Operations team was responsible for managing infrastructure for the Volkswagen Group. The team operates central backend data centers, servers and core services for the Volkswagen Group - following a traditional Enterprise IT approach.

Then, in Q3/2015 the Volkswagen Group IT decided to go with OpenStack for their new internal private cloud project. And the Operations team had an additional task and a new challenge: Bring OpenStack into production and run it.

This was the day when the Group IT Cloud Operations team’s excellent adventure to the land of OpenStack and cloud began.

In this session the team will provide insight into the challenges it faced, the solutions it found, and the day to day issues it experiences with clashes between the classic IT world and the new cloud world.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Technical and organizational transformation is the biggest challenge for enterprise users of OpenStack - like Volkswagen. To be successful in this transformation means to cope successfully with conflicting requirements between traditional and Enterprise IT, and the requirements of the cloud universe with its rapid and agile approach. The majority of the challenges are related to culture, peoples’ mindsets, organization, workflows and processes - not to the technology of Openstack.

This session will provide deep insight into the challenges a traditionally organized IT department will face when adopting cloud as a delivery model for their services.
schedule.title: Ops Log Book: Volkswagen’s Group IT Operations Team’s Adventurous Journey to the Land of OpenStack

videos.name: Ops Log Book: Volkswagen’s Group IT Operations Team’s Adventurous Journey to the Land of OpenStack

schedule.description:
Microservices are at the heart of the open cloud. Join us for a thought-provoking session where we will help you understand what it takes to build and run a modern, cloud-native application using open cloud technologies such as OpenStack, Cloud Foundry, and containers.

In this first step on your journey to building a successful microservices application, we will begin by considering the 12 factor app (12factor.net) and how modern applications are designed and run. We will then delve into the critical architectural decisions that facilitate scalable and resilient application development. As you finish this session, you will not only have a better understanding of how to architect a microservices application, you'll walk away with a better understanding of the options available to you.
